webTitle: Police happy with Euro 2000 dry run

fields.headline: Police happy with Euro 2000 dry run
fields.standfirst: Keegan vows to make Shearer earn his place
fields.trailText: Belgian police yesterday pronounced themselves satisfied with their security dress rehearsal for Euro 2000, although about 50 people were detained during the 2-2 draw in Brussels between the co-hosts Belgium and Holland.
fields.body:
Belgian police yesterday pronounced themselves satisfied with their security dress rehearsal for Euro 2000, although about 50 people were detained during the 2-2 draw in Brussels between the co-hosts Belgium and Holland.

"Everything went very smoothly and we are ready for the championships," said a police spokesman, Christian de Coninck.

Most of the arrests were for drunkenness, vandalism and ticket touting, but all bar two Dutch fans were released after Wednesday night's friendly.

The week's other friendlies brought mixed fortunes for England's Euro 2000 group opponents.

Portugal scored an impressive 2-1 win over Denmark in Lisbon. Their goals came from a Rui Costa penalty and an individual effort from Barcelona's Luis Figo.

"That's the open football we like but it has to be solid football too," the coach Humberto Coelho said. "What we want is to tighten up our game."

The Germans earned favourable reviews for their 1-1 draw with Croatia on a waterlogged pitch in Zagreb but the press expressed little faith in the attacking duo of Ulf Kirsten and Oliver Bierhoff.

Romania produced a dismal display in losing 2-0 in Greece. Team morale was indicated by the midfielder Dorinel Munteanu, who was quoted as saying: "We had no excuses but [the coach Emerich] Ienei must find excuses for himself."

webTitle: Keegan vows to make Shearer earn his place

fields.headline: Keegan vows to make Shearer earn his place
fields.standfirst:
The England coach is resolved not to let his captain call the tune
Police happy with Euro 2000 dry run
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan yesterday confirmed that Alan Shearer is not guaranteed a place in his Euro 2000 team and that Joe Cole is likely to miss out on a place in the squad.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday confirmed that Alan Shearer is not guaranteed a place in his Euro 2000 team and that Joe Cole is likely to miss out on a place in the squad.

Cole's star might be in the ascendancy as Shearer's is about to fall. But Keegan, heeding Howard Wilkinson's advice, said the West Ham prodigy will, injuries permitting, miss the cut for his final 22 and instead be among those juniors asked along to Belgium and the Netherlands for the ride, to train and adapt to the senior set-up.

Keegan, returning from watching the Under-21s triumph 3-0 over Yugoslavia in Barcelona, expressed support for Shearer that for the first time contained an equivocal note. "Alan's still got to perform well," Keegan said.

"The future will not involve Alan Shearer from the minute Euro 2000 is over. But although we haven't got that many English players in the Premiership, we have got an abundance of quality strikers. If I think I need to change Alan Shearer, I will. People underestimate us if they think otherwise."

That immediately prompted memories of Gary Lineker, shoulders hunched, making a premature departure from his final international, the defeat against Sweden in Euro 92.

Keegan also revealed that Shearer had attempted to inform him of his impending retirement six months ago. "But we didn't have a chance to meet," said Keegan. "When we did, I said I'd thought he was going to ask me for a game of golf.

"I said I'm not going to try and change your mind but I can promise you that you will not find anything to replace international football. It leaves a massive void."

Keegan added that in the longer term Shearer would be more than welcome to join the England training sessions, as Peter Beardsley and Stuart Pearce do now, in a supporting capacity.

Listening to the sage utterances of Wilkinson, the Under-21s coach and the FA's technical director, concerning the need to develop fragile young talent cautiously appears to have reined in Keegan's inclination to throw in the 18-year-old Cole as England's wild-card option at the European Championships.

"The future is all his," said Keegan, "and he is a player we would like to see more of. But a lot of common sense has been talked this week about his development and getting that right is important to Harry Redknapp, Howard Wilkinson and it will be to me.

"I would like to take two or three young players in the summer and Joe Cole would certainly be one of those if, as seems likely, he is not in the squad."

Others looking certain to miss out are the injured duo of Graeme le Saux, of Chelsea, and David Batty, of Leeds. But such stalwarts as Tony Adams will be included even if, hypothetically, they were not likely to be fit until after the opening game, against Portugal in Eindhoven on June 12.

Of his recuperating Liverpool strikers, Keegan is very confident that Michael Owen will be available and hopeful that Robbie Fowler will return for the last four games of the domestic season to advance his claim.

Of the runners and riders, Keegan wants to assess the resurgent form of Everton's Nick Barmby and, as timely as ever, Darren Anderton of Tottenham.

Wednesday's emphatic win for the Under-21s has strengthened the cases for several players, including Emile Heskey, Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard.

"If I had to pick out individual performances," said Keegan, "it would be those of Gerrard, for his all-round game, his tackling, use of the ball and his commitment; Jamie Carragher, with his thoroughly professional performance and the way he controlled the game from the back; Frank Lampard, a leader and steady as ever; Rio Ferdinand did a man-marking job as well as you could expect; and Kieron Dyer's running was notable."

 The FA is hoping to hear this morning that Uefa will grant its appeal, backed by Germany, Spain and Italy, for an extra 24 hours to name the final 22 for the summer's Euro 2000 tournament. At present the deadline is midnight on May 31, two hours after England have played Ukraine at Wembley.

webTitle: Clubs in line for £2bn TV bonanza

fields.headline: Clubs in line for £2bn TV bonanza
fields.standfirst: Top teams to show agreed games on their own channels and websites
fields.trailText: Premiership clubs are set to generate millions of pounds in extra revenue by being granted the right to broadcast their matches on their own channels and on the internet.
fields.body:
Premiership clubs are set to generate millions of pounds in extra revenue by being granted the right to broadcast their matches on their own channels and on the internet as part of a revolutionary television deal to be outlined next week.

All 20 Premier League chairmen are to meet in London on Monday to discuss the tender document that has been drawn up for potential broadcasters hoping to bid for football rights for the next three years following weeks of consultation between Richard Scudamore, the Premier League chief executive, and the clubs.

The document has to have the approval of at least 14 of the 20 Premier League clubs before it is sent to the interested broadcasters, who are likely to include all the main terrestrial and satellite channels.

It is believed that the document will recommend a number of rights packages - a departure from the current one-off exclusive deal for the broadcasting of live football - designed to appease the country's bigger clubs who are insisting that they should be given some individual rights to games so that they can cash in on their popularity.

Under the new deal, one package containing some 60 live games is to be put up for tender and a second package with fewer live games is also to be made available to broadcasters. This could lead to one broadcaster having rights over Sunday afternoon games, for example, and another having rights to a limited number of midweek games. A highlights package will also be made available.

The money from these three sections of the new deal will be put into a central fund and distributed among the 20 Premier League clubs.

Premier League officals, however, are keen to strike a balance between meeting the collective needs of all the clubs and the desire of the country's bigger clubs to make the most of modern technology and benefit from owning individual rights.

Under the new deal, all clubs will be given archive rights to their games, which would allow them to broadcast their matches within days of them taking place. Given that most clubs already have their own television channels and are in partnership with media companies, they would be able to show their games on their in-house channels.

Under the existing deal, the broadcaster owns the rights to games that have been on television and clubs can only show matches with their permission.

An element of pay-per-view is also expected to be introduced but the Premier League is anxious not to allow clubs too much freedom over which games they can select as this could affect any central package for live games.

Clubs will also be given internet rights to their games, which they will initially be allowed to broadcast soon after they have taken place, but later on a live basis. Club internet sites will be able to generate substantial funds through advertising once they can broadcast matches.

Clubs will be allowed to keep any money generated from these components and this will greatly benefit teams such as Manchester United and Liverpool, who could earn millions of pounds by appealing to a global audience through new technology.

The Premier League believes that an "unbundling" of football rights is the only way to satisfy the country's leading clubs.

Under the current four-year deal, which is due to conclude at the end of the 2000-01 season, BSkyB has the sole right to broadcast live football while the BBC can screen highlights. The deal is worth £743m.

According to some estimates, the core part of the new deal (two live packages and the highlights package) could earn clubs as much as £2bn with the bigger clubs set to earn even more through individual rights.

Premier League officals are satisfied with the impact the previous two television deals have had on football but believe that radical changes now need to be made to take into account the new technology available to clubs.

A spokesman for the Premier League said: "The balance with the last two television deals has been very good. However, we are now in a new era with new possibilites which we have to respond to.

"It will be a genuinely open bidding process and everyone starts on an equal basis. There's a big challenge in balancing up all the interests that are at play here."

Scudamore has met officals from the European Union's competition department to assure them that the bidding process will be open and fair.

The meeting on Monday is expected to be heated, however, given that many of the smaller Premier League clubs are concerned that the packages on offer will increase the gap between the rich and the poor.

The smaller clubs are anxious to ensure that all rights are sold collectively and money distributed to all 20 Premier League members, but given the power of the country's leading clubs, who are also enviously eyeing the riches being earned by their European counterparts through exclusive television deals, this appears unlikely.

webTitle: From the makers of PlayStation: An online bank

fields.headline: From the makers of PlayStation: An online bank
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sony's chairman, Norio Ohaga, and president Nobuyuki Idei announce their company's online banking alliance with JP Morgan and Japan's Sakura Bank.
fields.body:
Sony's chairman, Norio Ohaga, and president Nobuyuki Idei announce their company's online banking alliance with JP Morgan and Japan's Sakura Bank.

The online bank, to be capitalised at ¥37.5bn (£222m), will be 80% owned by Sony, 16% by Sakura and 4% by JP Morgan.

It is due to begin services in the first half of 2001 with a target of one trillion yen in deposits within five years. Sony hopes it will generate an annual profit by its third year.

But while it is aiming high, analysts did not expect Sony to become a big financial player overnight. "Sony is still after all an amateur in this field," said Masahiro Ono, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read.

The online banking announcement helped fuel a 5.6% rise in Sony's shares in Tokyo to ¥14,500. The consumer electronics company is to establish a US holding company, Sony Broadband Entertainment, to house Sony Music Entertainment and Sony Pictures Entertainment.

The holding company will work to strengthen Sony's online content distribution and examine possible strategic alliances.

"This would stamp out speculation that we may sell the US entertainment units, and shows our strong commitment in reinforcing the content businesses," said Mr Idei.

Sony is also thinking of listing its internet provider, Sony Communication Network. And it plans to issue $57.3m in convertible bonds to raise money for incentive plans for executives at its US subsidiaries.

fields.headline: Stumbling Tiger predicts hi-tech collapse
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Julian Robertson, one of the world's most successful hedge fund managers, yesterday warned that investor enthusiasm for hi-tech stocks was creating "a pyramid destined for collapse" as he announced the closure of his ie Tiger Management investment company.
fields.body:
Julian Robertson, one of the world's most successful hedge fund managers, yesterday warned that investor enthusiasm for hi-tech stocks was creating "a pyramid destined for collapse" as he announced the closure of his ie Tiger Management investment company.

In an emotional letter to his remaining clients yesterday, Mr Robertson said he could not continue to risk their money in "a market which frankly I do not understand".

The 67-year-old's decision to withdraw from actively managing other people's money comes after his hedge funds lost $16bn (£10bn) in value over the past 18 months.

Tiger's underperformance echoes that of other "value investors," including Warren Buffett, the world's wealthiest investment manager, who failed to invest in internet companies and focused on "old economy" stocks.

Mr Robertson left with a rallying cry for value investors. "The key to Tiger's success over the years has been a steady commitment to buying the best stocks and shorting the worst," he wrote.

"In a rational environment, this strategy works well. But in an irrational market, where earnings and price considerations take a back seat to mouse clicks and momentum, such logic, as we have learned, does not count for much."

Investors have withdrawn $7.7bn from Tiger since it started to stumble badly in August 1998.

Mr Robertson is expected to keep a small staff in his Manhattan office to continue to manage some $1.5bn of his own money. Some 150 hedge fund managers employed around the world are expected to leave with liberal benefits, according to a company spokesman yesterday.

A further $500,000 belonging to the company's partners could also be managed by Mr Robertson. With most of the company's portfolio already liquidated, the remainder will be returned to remaining investors.

Tiger holds substantial stakes in a number of industrial companies, such as its 22% of US Airways.

The company is expected to put these into a separate fund in order to prevent the shares from crashing as a result of simply dumping them on the stock market. Shares in US Airways were trading down yesterday.

Mr Robertson's ability to pick underperforming companies and to take aggressive bets on the direction of the world's economies made him one of the most successful hedge fund managers alongside George Soros.

Even after the recent disastrous performance, the Tiger funds returned an annual average of 25% in the 20 years to the end of February.

Hedge funds charge clients, who tend to be wealthy indi viduals or institutional investors, a hefty percentage of any annual profits. Failure to make any profits directly reduces its ability to pay staff bonuses.

Mr Soros's funds, still valued at some $19.1bn, also suffered from an aversion to technology stocks last year.

However, the performance of Quantum, the Soros flagship fund, has improved significantly since then with a 5% increase since the beginning of the year, compared with Tiger's 14% downturn in the two months to the end of February.

Mr Robertson, who was recently ranked as the ninth best investor of the 20th century, started Tiger in 1980.

A firm supporter of the financial sector, he championed Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns, Well Fargo and Bank America.

In 1998, Tiger saw $2bn wiped out in a matter of hours as the Japanese yen surged against the dollar.

fields.bylineHtml: Jane Martinson in New York

fields.headline: Magic on a shoestring
fields.standfirst:
A Midsummer Night's Dream
The Tobacco Factory, Bristol
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: Andrew Hilton's brilliantly clear, beautifully simple production is played on an almost totally bare rectangular space with the audience sitting on three sides. Yet despite its minimalism, it conjures up a rare sense of enchantment, creating the feeling that it would be easy to slip between the parallel worlds of humans and fairies. To do this with just a single strand of fairy lights, music and unaccompanied voices is something of an achievement.
fields.body:
Andrew Hilton's brilliantly clear, beautifully simple production is played on an almost totally bare rectangular space with the audience sitting on three sides. Yet despite its minimalism, it conjures up a rare sense of enchantment, creating the feeling that it would be easy to slip between the parallel worlds of humans and fairies. To do this with just a single strand of fairy lights, music and unaccompanied voices is something of an achievement.

There is something so fresh and unforced about this production that it reminds me of early Shakespeare productions by the young Deborah Warner. Hilton and his cast tell the story with no fuss but with an exceptional eye for detail. Even the social standing of each of the Mechanicals is clearly delineated; this is not just the usual gaggle of clowns. With merely a dash of eyeliner and an earring they are suddenly and completely transformed into Cobweb, Pease Blossom and Mustard Seed. There are so many similar moments that you wonder if Hilton has his own theatrical magic wand.

The lovers, in their various permutations, take centre stage in this production, which celebrates both the transforming power of love and of theatre itself. Mark Buffery's Theseus/Oberon rules the roost with iron charm both in Athens and the enchanted forest, a kind of benign magician ensuring that true love runs its course. Dee Sadler's wonderfully still, watchful Hippolyta is in thrall to him but also suggests that she has got the measure of the man.

There is not a dud performance, and there are some very fine ones: a sly Puck from Chris Donnelly who revels in others' misfortune and turns up later as a discomforted flunky at the wedding celebrations; an excellent Quince (Peter Clifford), obviously a veteran of amateur dramatics; and a most enjoyable and surprising Flute from John Mackay, whose initial reluctance to play the hapless heroine Thisbe in the Mechanicals' play turns into a Sarah Bernhardt-type enthusiasm for the role.

This is a lovely production, a really great evening out and further proof of how those with real energy and imagination working in the regions are increasingly eschewing theatre buildings in favour of other spaces.

 Until April 8. Box office: 07989 468584.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

There is something so fresh and unforced about this production that it reminds me of early Shakespeare productions by the young Deborah Warner. Hilton and his cast tell the story with no fuss but with an exceptional eye for detail. Even the social standing of each of the Mechanicals is clearly delineated; this is not just the usual gaggle of clowns. With merely a dash of eyeliner and an earring they are suddenly and completely transformed into Cobweb, Pease Blossom and Mustard Seed. There are so many similar moments that you wonder if Hilton has his own theatrical magic wand. The lovers, in their various permutations, take centre stage in this production, which celebrates both the transforming power of love and of theatre itself. Mark Buffery's Theseus/Oberon rules the roost with iron charm both in Athens and the enchanted forest, a kind of benign magician ensuring that true love runs its course. Dee Sadler's wonderfully still, watchful Hippolyta is in thrall to him but also suggests that she has got the measure of the man. There is not a dud performance, and there are some very fine ones: a sly Puck from Chris Donnelly who revels in others' misfortune and turns up later as a discomforted flunky at the wedding celebrations; an excellent Quince (Peter Clifford), obviously a veteran of amateur dramatics; and a most enjoyable and surprising Flute from John Mackay, whose initial reluctance to play the hapless heroine Thisbe in the Mechanicals' play turns into a Sarah Bernhardt-type enthusiasm for the role. This is a lovely production, a really great evening out and further proof of how those with real energy and imagination working in the regions are increasingly eschewing theatre buildings in favour of other spaces.  Until April 8. fields.headline: Railtrack goes cap in hand
fields.standfirst:
Chief executive asks government for a further £1bn a year in aid

More about transport
fields.trailText:
Chief executive asks government for a further £1bn a year in aid

More about transport
fields.body:
Railtrack yesterday presented a £1 bn a year begging bowl to the government saying the cash was needed to turn Britain's railways into a world class system over the next 12 years.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said the money would have to come from the Treasury. The company said it would not need to be funded by fare increases because passenger numbers were rising by 4% a year - ensuring agrowing revenue scheme.

Mr Corbett's message to the government was that the industry was prepared to invest but that it could not be expected to continue to shoulder an increasing financial burden in view of reducing subsidies.

He said Railtrack received an annual revenue of £2.4 bn from access charges, but this would have to increase £1bn a year by 2006, if Railtrack was to carry out necessary improvements on the network.

At the beginning of privatisation in 1996, subsidies started at £2bn, but by 2002 when most of the franchises with the train operating companies are due to be re newed, they will be down to £900m. They will have to be reviewed and renewed.

Industry observers were astonished at Railtrack's demands and its admittance that it will still have to rely heavily on the taxpayer for assistance. One expert said: "It begs the question: why was the industry privatised when it needs to be substantially underpinned by the state?"

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority, welcomed Railtrack's investment plans, but did not believe that the company had the resources to finance improvements required to meet "excessive congestion".

Bernard Jenkin, shadow minister of transport, said that Railtrack's demands could not be magicked of thin air. "Either ticket prices will rise a lot, or the government will have to come up with big lumps of cash, or both."

Mr Corbett would like to see £52 bn invested in the industry over the next 12 years, but admitted that the realistic figure was £8bn over the next five years. Even this is subject to a review on how much Railtrack can charge train companies to use track and signalling.

Of the £8bn, £3bn has already been committed on projects like improvements to the west coast main line, the Sunderland Metro, station upgrades, and safety improvements on trains following the Paddington rail crash.

A further £2.5 bn has been earmarked for modernising the line into Manchester, the Coventry and Birmingham route, London to Stansted airport, and the trans-Pennine route from Leeds to Manchester. The remaining £2.5 bn is due to come from schemes approved by Sir Alastair.

In a terse warning both to the government and the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, Railtrack called on them to "back off" and give the company space.

It said: "The regulatory and political stance will need to give the financial markets the confidence that Railtrack will not be subject to a disproportionate level of regulation and political intervention, including fines and enforcement action."

Mr Corbett is furious with Mr Winsor for imposing a fine of £10m - "the largest corporate penalty ever levelled against a British company" - for falling short of a 12.5% improvement in performance demanded by the regulator last year.

Mr Corbett is refusing to make up the shortfall next year and could face a further fine of £8m.

webTitle: World Online founder takes market to brink

fields.headline: World Online founder takes market to brink
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A multi-millionaire Dutch businesswoman could have single-handedly spooked the European market for internet shares, it appeared yesterday.
fields.body:
A multi-millionaire Dutch businesswoman could have single-handedly spooked the European market for internet shares, it appeared yesterday.

Nina Brink, the 46-year-old founder of World Online, sold 1.2m shares in the company just a day after its €12bn flotation last week.

Her divestment has only just come to light because it was carried out in the name of an obscure US private equity house. However, the transaction has sent World Online's shares plummeting 40% below their debut price.

In any normal market, Mrs Brink's windfall would suggest, at worst, a slightly worrying lack of confidence in her company's future share performance. However, in these edgy days of internet hysteria, the transaction has fuelled fundamental concerns about "herd mentality" in dot.com valuations.

Technology shares had a bad day yesterday, falling 7% in London. That added to a desperate week, which has seen the likes of Lycos and Lastminute.com sink far below their ambitious flotation valuations. Lastminute ended the day down 35p at a low of 252p.

To analysts, the most worrying feature of the incident is that it suggests few investors read the World Online prospectus. The document clearly stated that Mrs Brink had siphoned off many of her shares to holding companies, which would not be covered by her six-month lock-in. However, everyone was deeply shocked when they realised she had sold.

Peter Bradshaw of Merrill Lynch says: "You certainly could not describe what's happened there as a net positive for the sector."

There is a growing feeling that European investors are taking too shallow a view of dot.com companies.

Sarah Skinner, of the hi-tech stockbroker Durlacher, says: "There's a big difference between investors in Europe and the US. In America, there's more actual interest in technology and in companies. In the UK and Europe, people just like the idea of getting rich quick rather than having any longer interest in the sector."

That has made European stocks even more volatile than US ones.

Ms Skinner believes it would be incorrect to suggest the dot.com bubble has burst, preferring to see the sell-off as "a pull-back to quality and a flight to reality".

The effect has been hastened by the arrival of more business-to-business e-commerce companies, which have a much faster route to profitability than the likes of lastminute.com and amazon.com, which are going after the consumer sales.

Sharon Coombs, an analyst at HSBC, says: "We're moving towards the more healthy view that not all of these companies are going to succeed. There's some questioning going on as to whether the new economy is really going to benefit over the next 20 years so much more than the rest of the market."

Internet service providers are feeling the pinch particularly badly - Freeserve fell 27p to 484p yesterday, its lowest point this year. There is a feeling that Europe is reaching a level of over-supply of these companies.

Among the others joining Lastminute.com were Scoot.com, which dropped 41p to £14.96 and QXL.com, which lost 57p to £10.60. The only consolation for lastminute's co-founder Martha Lane Fox is that another dot.com woman, Ms Brink, is feeling the heat.

webTitle: Barclays under fire over top pay

fields.headline: Barclays under fire over top pay
fields.trailText: The chairman of Barclays Bank received a four-fold increase in pay last year while the bank's new chief executive, Matt Barrett, picked up £1.3m for three months' work - equal to £14,400 a day.
fields.body:
The chairman of Barclays Bank received a four-fold increase in pay last year while the bank's new chief executive, Matt Barrett, picked up £1.3m for three months' work - equal to £14,400 a day.

Sir Peter Middleton, a former Treasury mandarin, banked £1.76m in 1999, compared to £408,000 a year earlier.

Details of the chairman's package, including a cash bonus of £800,000, were published in the bank's annual report and accounts a week before it is due to close 171 branches, affecting 500 staff.

Last year the bank, now Britain's third biggest, recorded a 30% improvement in profits to £2.5bn. It has been leading the move by banks to start levying new charges on cash machine withdrawals and was singled out in the government's review of the banking industry for particular criticism.

Sir Peter's rise was due mainly to his taking over the chief executive's role for much of the year as well after the US banker, Michael O'Neill, fell ill the day he was due to take up that post. Mr Barrett's £1.3m for his first three months included a cash bonus of more than £680,000.

The increases were condemned by finance union Unifi. Deputy general secretary Iain MacLean said: "It is insensitive that Barclays directors shoud have received massive increases in remuneration at a time when everyone is doing their best to cut costs to maintain the group's competitive position."

webTitle: BT joins US blue-chips for licence bid

fields.headline: BT joins US blue-chips for licence bid
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BT yesterday further strengthened its partnership with software group Microsoft and leading US telecommunications group AT&T to win a third generation mobile telephone licence.
fields.body:
BT yesterday further strengthened its partnership with software group Microsoft and leading US telecommunications group AT&T to win a third generation mobile telephone licence.

BT already has a software deal with Microsoft's Genie which sends data such as football scores and share prices direct to mobile phones, and an international roaming alliance with AT&T.

BT is also developing and trialling a third generation mobile network on the Isle of Man. The government is auctioning five mobile phone operating licences and yesterday BT was one of seven bidders making an offer of £1.55bn for one of those licences.

But the alliance is to go deeper, with the three companies working together to develop new applications for the consumer and business mobile markets.

While the applications are targeted at third generation mobile phones some will be deployed on existing services.

Sohail Qadri, director of BT mobility, said: "Applications are key to customers. By working with AT&T Wireless and Microsoft we will provide our customers with advanced, innovative and higher speed mobile internet applications, giving them true multimedia capability while on the move."

None of the firms would reveal the level of their investment in mobile applications.

fields.headline: A second coming
fields.standfirst:
The High Fidelity
Union Chapel, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: There are a few things you would expect to find in a chapel, but a band attempting their own second coming probably isn't one of them. For Sean Dickson, this resurrection means shrugging off his past as the singer of early 90s indie wannabes the Soup Dragons and finally living up to the words of their one hit, I'm Free. Now shorn of his bowl-cut, he's the voice and vision behind the unique and downright odd The High Fidelity.
fields.body:
There are a few things you would expect to find in a chapel, but a band attempting their own second coming probably isn't one of them. For Sean Dickson, this resurrection means shrugging off his past as the singer of early 90s indie wannabes the Soup Dragons and finally living up to the words of their one hit, I'm Free. Now shorn of his bowl-cut, he's the voice and vision behind the unique and downright odd The High Fidelity.

Appearing as part of the John Peel sessions for Radio 1 in order to showcase their debut album, Demonstration, Dickson and the band are clearly enjoying themselves. And who can blame them? Demonstration, a patchwork quilt of an album, stitches Bollywood movies, Slade and Led Zeppelin together to make often beautiful, never boring pop songs. As Indian strings fill the air and Greeneye Monster begins, Dickson has every right to smile. He's made a hybrid Sgt Pepper in his bedroom, with a better sense of humour and a lot less self-consciousness, and brought it to screaming life.

Kazoos, a toy keyboard, stylophones and an Omnichord - a bizarre electric violin - make appearances in songs Jarvis Cocker would kill for and musos will find strangely familiar. Ithanku has a bassline that's pure Motown and would fit snugly on to George Harrison's All Things Must Pass, while The National Anthem, with its vocoder vocals, is Plastic Ono Band meets Primal Scream on a street in New Delhi. Yet The High Fidelity sound completely new and completely different from anything around at the moment, comparable only, in terms of imagination and creativity, to the Super Furry Animals. The band plays with passion and energy - there's excitement in the air.

Dickson's eclectic vision is realised by a wall of sound Phil Spector would be proud of, created by fellow band members Paul Dallaway on guitar and Adrian Barry on bass. But it's drummer Ross McFarlane who gives songs like the epic Odyssey of a Psychonaut their power and commerciality - this is 70s-style prog rock you can groove to.

His hand in the air, one finger pointing to the heavens, Dickson poses a question: "On radio and enjoying yourself at the same time. How good can this be?" The High Fidelity prove it can be very good indeed.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Piping hot stuff
fields.standfirst:
Vaganza (Northern Sinfonia)/Fischer
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: Links between Messiaen, John Adams, Stravinsky and traditional Northumbrian pipes may seem few and far between, yet this concert given by Vaganza, the contemporary music wing of the Northern Sinfonia, attempted to bring these diffuse elements together.
fields.body:
Links between Messiaen, John Adams, Stravinsky and traditional Northumbrian pipes may seem few and far between, yet this concert given by Vaganza, the contemporary music wing of the Northern Sinfonia, attempted to bring these diffuse elements together.

Kathryn Tickell has established herself as one of the foremost exponents of the Northumbrian pipes. A diminutive, hand-blown cousin of the lung-busting Highland bagpipes, the Northumbrian instrument is the most delicate of the bagpipe family. The first half of the concert was a masterclass in the pipes' versatility: as a plaintive solo instrument in two traditional melodies, as part of a classical chamber ensemble in Tickell's new work Lordenshaws, and as a live counterpoint to electro-acoustic sounds on tape in John Casken's Piper's Linn.

There will always be dangers in combining instruments and styles from two different traditions, and Casken's piece, composed in 1984, did not escape some of the pitfalls. While there were some ingenious sonic transitions from live to recorded sound, Piper's Linn was mostly a disembodied dialogue between the pipes' coarse chromaticism and the tape's swoops and growls.

But Tickell's Lordenshaws created a meaningful connection between pipes and classical instrumentalists, at least in its intensely melodic opening. With the drone of the pipes providing a musical lodestar, a string trio contributed a haunting chain of suspended dissonances that Tickell then joined with a modal, pining melody.

Tickell's piece was most assured in its clear textures and slow-moving harmonies. When the music became denser and faster, it sounded self-conscious and forced, and the seams of Tickell's compositional technique started to show. But there were moments when tradition and interpretation seemed precisely aligned.

The manic energy of Stravinsky's weird, grimacing Ragtime was matched in the second half by Adams's Chamber Symphony. With its eclectic basis in music for cartoons and Schoenberg's own Chamber Symphony, Adams's magpie-like musicality found an unusually sympathetic interpreter in conductor Thierry Fischer. He managed to make sense of Adams's compact instrumentation in the opening, and relished the second movement's relative calm.

But violinist Bradley Creswick stole the show in the last movement, Roadrunner, with a brilliantly harassed solo. Opening the second half, Messiaen's Sept Haikai showed the all-round excellence of Vaganza's ensemble, as well as Huw Watkins's magnificent, diamond-machined precision in the piano part.

fields.headline: Bracewell fired by Fulham
fields.trailText: Paul Bracewell yesterday paid the inevitable price for Fulham's failure to be in realistic contention for the play-offs when he was dismissed as manager of the First Division club.
fields.body:
Paul Bracewell yesterday paid the inevitable price for Fulham's failure to be in realistic contention for the play-offs when he was dismissed as manager of the First Division club.

The axe was wielded with typical ruthlessness by the club's owner Mohamed Al Fayed who is now looking for his fifth manager in less than three years.

The news was broken to Bracewell after training. Fulham's former Germany striker Karlheinz Riedle is expected to be named as interim manager today and he will be asked to prepare the team for Saturday's visit by Crystal Palace.

"It's all happened because of results," said Fulham's PR consultant Max Clifford. "We were drawing or losing games we felt we should have been winning, and the view was that that was not going to change.

"We are not in a strong position and it's a really tall order to make the play-offs now, but we're still optimistic. The chairman and the board had a meeting in the morning and made the decision. The search for a new manager has started."

Bracewell, 37, always knew he was on a sticky wicket at Craven Cottage, saying recently that Al Fayed had told him he wanted promotion in the first year. The former England international's record since being appointed manager last May is 22 wins, 17 draws and 12 defeats, the last of them by the only goal at Ipswich last Saturday, which left Fulham in 10th place and 10 points away from the play-off positions.

Al Fayed has big plans for the club, including a redeveloped 30,000-seat stadium, and needs Premiership football to sustain them. However, he has made money available to his managers, Bracewell alone spending more than £5m.

Barry Hayles, the Fulham striker, was shocked at yesterday's news. "Paul took training this morning and there was no indication that anything was wrong. We had seven games to go and thought we could make the play-offs."

Bracewell was the assistant manager to Kevin Keegan, the Fulham chief operating officer who moved on to take the full-time job as England manager after leading them to the Second Division title last season.

The former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear and Manchester United's retired captain Eric Cantona have been sounded out and seemingly ruled out, but it is rumoured that Fulham are expecting to appoint a French manager with a proven track record.

fields.headline: Professional licences? What about character?
fields.standfirst: Plans to bring managerial qualifications into line with those in Europe will be a kick in the teeth for all-round entertainment
fields.trailText: Plans to bring managerial qualifications into line with those in Europe will be a kick in the teeth for all-round entertainment.
fields.body:
After a week in which the FA's technical director Howard Wilkinson announced a plan to issue professional licences similar to those operating in most European countries, the news that Karlheinz Riedle has been appointed the manager of Fulham should be welcomed by fans everywhere.

No doubt there will be many critics ready to point out the irony that Riedle, like Gianluca Vialli, would not be entitled to take a coaching job in his own country. His supporters will offer in evidence cases such as David Platt, whose six uncomfortable and unlicensed matches at Sampdoria, not to mention a grisly season at Nottingham Forest, suggest he would have benefited from a few months in the classroom.

Yet it is hard to overestimate the damage this proposal would do to the entertainment value of the English game - unless the structure of the course for prospective club managers reflected a certain whimsical eccentricity not normally associated with the former Leeds and Sheffield Wednesday boss, the game will surely suffer.

Where would we be, for example, if there was no place for Michael Knighton? How much duller would the footballing life of this country have been without Jimmy Sirrel? Or Barry Fry? Or (except for the fans of the teams he has managed), Alan Ball? Some of our managers have possessed skills bordering on genius - Colin Murphy's programme notes spring to mind - that simply cannot be taught.

However much he achieves at Fulham, Riedle is unlikely to reach such heights. Nevertheless, it is the kind of appointment that gives you hope for the future: a hopeful punt on untested glamour (well, he's foreign isn't he?) by a club with, frankly, more money than sense still offers the possibility of eventual embarrassment for all concerned. Wilkinson's dismal plan threatens to put a stop to all that. No more big-name veteran players plucked desperately from the ranks to halt the slide of a falling giant (hi Stuart). No more grotesque mismatches of ego-driven Dutchmen and earthy northern under-achievers. In short, a lot more competence and a lot less fun.

While it is admittedly unlikely that Eric Cantona will be offered the long-term position at Fulham, the mere fact that his name has been mentioned is enough to excite all those football fans who enjoy seeing the rich and famous falling flat on their backsides through such spectacular misjudgments. Which is obviously all of us.

webTitle: United to be held by Redknappers

fields.headline: United to be held by Redknappers
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with the 20% stake in a greyhound stable, looks at the footballing facts - and completely ignores them
fields.trailText: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with the 20% stake in a greyhound stable, looks at the footballing facts - and completely ignores them
fields.body:
For openers, here are some facts. Frank McAvennie was on the pitch - and the mullet was considered dashing - the last time West Ham won at Old Trafford. Manchester United are playing their best football of the season, not just here but all over Europe; and only a man who has lost all his senses would even consider the away win for Harry Redknapp's side on Saturday. Digest these truths then look at the odds Ladbrokes are offering on a Hammers victory. Eights. Tempting, for sure, but can it happen? Probably not - but the draw looks good at fours.

It's fair to say that to beat the young Fergusonians, you need a clear two-goal lead before half time. Liverpool went one-up recently, but that was only enough to earn a false sense of security - the game ended in a stalemate. As things stand, it looks as if Saturday's West Ham side should contain enough firepower for at least one goal. And not just Italian flavoured firepower.

Up front with Paolo Di Canio, the visitors should field loan striker Frederic Kanoute. The Olympique Lyonnais star, rated somewhere round the £6m mark, could not have been impressive on his only game to date for the bubble-blowing East Londoners. The only downside of a blinding performance at the weekend would be the inevitable deluge of King Canute inspired headlines, but if that's the price of cleaning 4-1 draw, so be it. Coventry got a three-goal pasting at Highbury last weekend but it may be worth chancing them to shade Saturday's home game against Liverpool. On paper this one looks so tight that it threatens to split at the seams, but four wins over the last six at home should shade it for the Sky Blues. The best value can be found at Coral who are offering a massively generous 5-2.

Gordon Strachan's Scottish international Paul Telfer had, by all accounts, a fine game against France on Wednesday and ought to feature at some stage. Slightly worrying, however, are the reports that Peruvian Ysrael Zuniga has picked up an injury on international duty against Paraguay. He was withdrawn after just 54 minutes and Strachan was counting on his availability should Robbie Keane be sidelined for a fourth week on the trot. Still, stick with the home side.

Elsewhere Everton look nailed on to demolish Watford at Goodison on Saturday. They've won seven of their seven competitive encounters with the Hornets and there's no reason to think another victory will be thwarted. Similarly Manchester City are sure to pick up three points at Swindon, where they've won five from six visits. Include both as bankers for your accumulator bets.

Recommended bets
Manchester United v West Ham - draw
Coventry v Liverpool - home win
Everton v Watford - home win
Swindon v Manchester City - away win

fields.headline: Heskey abuse taints play-off win
fields.standfirst:
England qualify as Liverpool striker suffers racial taunts and spitting
Campbell 24, Lampard 49pen, Hendrie 64
Leader comment
War on racism renewed after Heskey ordeal
fields.trailText: Emile Heskey had to endure racial abuse and spitting as England's Under-21 side qualified for their own European Championship finals in a play-off last night.
fields.byline: Pete Lansley at the Mini Estadi, Barcelona
fields.body:
Emile Heskey had to endure racial abuse and spitting as England's Under-21 side qualified for their own European Championship finals in a play-off last night.

The Football Association's executive director David Davies took decisive action at half-time by asking Uefa delegates to deal with racist taunting from the stands.

The Liverpool striker also received more than his fair share of physical attention, which left the England Under-21 manager Howard Wilkinson saying: "Emile had a torrid time of it out there. He was subject to unreasonable behaviour. I said to Dave Sexton [coaching assistant] it was like going back 15 years. I thought we'd moved on from those days."

The FA will not be taking further action over the abuse which came from one Yugoslav supporter. Heskey said: "I was aware of what was going on in the stands. It's not something you come across in the Premiership.There was a bit of everything going on out there. I was spat at one time but the manager had said this is something I might come across."

On the positive side England's juniors, playing in a compact 16,000-seat stadium in the shadow of the Nou Camp, took full advantage of an opportunity to stake claims for roles on a grander stage.

Kevin Keegan, pondering his selection for Euro 2000 from the stands, must have been impressed as the prime candidates on view came through their differing trials with reputations enhanced.

In Steven Gerrard's performance and Heskey's show of character under pressure, the England coach knows he has two youngsters who can become men at this summer.

Barcelona's reserves play at this open-topped ground and England's own back-up side now progress to play in Slova kia from May 26 to June 4. But which of the players who shone last night are to be withdrawn for senior duty will become a matter for debate over the next two months.

Before the match, Keegan took the opportunity to raise Gerrard's stature even before he had kicked a ball. Denied a senior debut last month by a groin injury days before the friendly with Argentina, the former England Under-18 captain has evidently lost no ground in Keegan's estimation.

"I'm very excited about Steve Gerrard," he said. "I've watched him more than any other young player this season and each time I've been impressed with the different things he does. I can't speak highly enough of him."

With David Batty unlikely to be fit for Euro 2000, Gerrard looks set to win his first cap in England's next friendly against Brazil on May 25. It was the Liverpool midfielder's quick thinking, in the 24th minute, that set Wilkinson's charges on their way last night.

In a fractious first half, Gerrard was upended but rose as quickly he fell. Releasing his free-kick into Heskey's path, the ball was transferred into the gap ahead of Andy Campbell. The Middlesbrough forward showed admirable composure on his debut at this level and dispatched the ball under Vladan Kujovic's right hand.

Like the abuse of Heskey, Yugoslavia's challenge subsided after the interval. Moments after Dejan Stankovic had whipped a dipping free-kick just over Richard Wright's bar, Jovan Tanasijevic, Heskey's tormentor-in-chief, handled as he jostled with Lee Hendrie for a high ball. Frank Lampard struck home the penalty with venom, his eighth goal in 16 appearances at this level.

England's place in a group with Italy, Turkey and Slovakia was made safe by Hendrie. Gerrard was at the hub of the action again, swinging a cross from right to left. Seth Johnson collected the ball and pulled a low cross back for the midfielder to control, check back and shoot.

England Under-21 (3-5-2)

Wright (Ipswich); Ferdinand (West Ham), Carragher (Liverpool), Barry (Aston Villa); Dyer (Newcastle), Lampard (West Ham); Gerrard (Liverpool), Hendrie (Aston Villa; Mills, Leeds, 87min), Johnson (Derby); Campbell (Middlesbrough; Cadamarteri, Everton, 87), Heskey (Liverpool; Davies, Southampton, 77).

Yugoslavia Under-21 (3-5-2):

Kujovic; Dzodic, Tanasijevic, Obradovic; Dudic ( Dokaj, 58), Duljaj, Lazetic, Vukomanovic, Boskovic; Stankovic ( Ivanovic, 90), Kezman.

Referee: H Strampe (Germany).

fields.headline: So farewell then...
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle says that the passing of Paul Bracewell is unfortunate, but that he can't have expected anything less
fields.trailText: To lose one manager maybe construed as careless. To lose four in four seasons suggests your chairman is Jesus Gil. Nevertheless, Mohammed Al Fayed's Fulham were today insisting that Paul Bracewell was sacked solely because of performances on the pitch.
fields.body:
To lose one manager maybe construed as careless. To lose four in four seasons suggests your chairman is Jesus Gil. Nevertheless, Mohammed Al Fayed's Fulham were today insisting that Paul Bracewell was sacked solely because of performances on the pitch.

"It's all happened because of results" insisted Fulham's PR guru Max Clifford. "We were drawing or losing games we felt we should have been winning and the view was that that wasn't going to change."

But Bracewell was up against it from the start. When he took the manager's job last May, he was immediately told by Al Fayed that he wanted Premiership football in a year's time. Nothing more, nothing less. Quite a requirement considering that Fulham were only just out of the Second division and had a fresh-faced young manager at the helm.

The team began well, but then started to stutter. Almost immediately the whispers began circling around like vultures in the tabloid press: Bracewell wasn't producing the results and had to be replaced, preferably by a high-profile name. Discussions actually took place between Cantona and Fulham.

Throughout all the rumours and lies, Bracewell remained quiet and modest - and behind the scenes worked harder than ever. As keeper Maik Taylor said earlier today: "I'm shocked. I wasn't expecting it at all. The mood in the dressing room has been fantastic, even though we've been disappointed with the results."

But the man never had a chance. For a start he wasn't the big name manager that Al Fayed craved. And he also faced an bunch of fans intoxicated by the promotion from the Second division - and who seemed to think that a bit of money gave them a divine right to promotion to the Premiership.

And so ten months after he took the manager's job at Fulham, Paul Bracewell has gone. Speculation has already moved on to who will replace him. But as he packs his bags and leaves Craven Cottage he should remember one thing: Bobby Robson was also sacked by Fulham after 10 months into his first managerial job in 1968 - and he didn't end up doing too badly.

webTitle: BNFL: the company they love to hate

fields.headline: BNFL: the company they love to hate
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) has attracted more adverse publicity in Britain and around the world in the last few months than any other company - and that includes BMW and its treatment of Rover.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) has attracted more adverse publicity in Britain and around the world in the last few months than any other company - and that includes BMW and its treatment of Rover.

In Japan, Germany and Switzerland, nuclear utilities have turned against it and frozen or cancelled orders. The Irish and Nordic governments, which have never liked BNFL, are demanding the closure of its Sellafield nuclear reprocessing works in Cumbria and an ending to the discharges of waste into the Irish Sea.

But is the company finished? The answer is a resounding no. Yesterday, the government decided it could not be privatised at least until 2002, but its contract to manage, with two other companies, the Aldermaston nuclear weapons factory in Berkshire and a sister facility at Burghfield in Oxfordshire was confirmed.

More importantly, the company is managing vast quantities of waste accumulated over 50 years of the nuclear weapons programme and development of civil nuclear power.

The spent fuel from British and overseas nuclear power stations and the plutonium and uranium recovered from reprocessing is stored and managed by the company at Sellafield. In addition there are many tanks of high dangerous heat producing liquid nuclear waste that has to be turned into glass blocks for safer storage.

This takes 50 years to cool down before it can be considered for storing in long-term repositories or for disposal in deep holes in the ground, for which sites have yet to be found. So we are stuck with them.

Despite its appalling reputation, BNFL remains the only company in the country and one of the few in the world that can deal with the leftovers of the cold war.

Not that its troubles are over. In February, it was given two months to come up with a plan to improve its management so safety was given the priority it deserved.

The threat by the government safety watchdogs, the nuclear installations inspectorate, was that, if it failed to do so, its lucrative reprocessing works would be shut down as a penalty.

The plan has still not been produced. BNFL is still in the midst of a storm and is set to remain the company anti-nuclear protestors worldwide most of all love to hate.

fields.headline: Sacked, Knacked and Hacked
fields.trailText: BRACES ARE OUT
fields.body:
BRACES ARE OUT

The Fiver was woken early this morning, around 11.45-ish, by a voice speaking in hushed tones. "You see that fugging Paul Bracewell?" Not right now, no, but let me remove my sleep-mask. "I don't have time for this fugging shenanigans. I am telling you he was sacked because of a conspiracy at the very top of the Britain's establishment." You mean Chris Evans was involved? "Fuggin' hell..."

Such shocking revelations take time to sink in, so the Fiver went back to sleep for a couple of hours. But the more you think about it, the more this mysterious caller has a point. Bracewell's record at Craven Cottage is not bad, with 22 wins and 17 draws this season, and until last weekend's defeat by Ipswich the promoted club were in with a shout of a play-off place. He also appears to have the respect of the players, and as club captain Chris Coleman said today: "It's hard for Paul and I feel very sorry for him because he has worked his tail off really."

Actually, Bracewell doesn't have a tail - it was lost in the evolutionary process some time ago - but neither does he have much of a media profile. He's just a former England international with little managerial experience. Not like Fulham's new caretaker boss Karl-Heinz Riedle. He played for Germany. Other famous people up for the job include Joe Kinnear (who revealed he was "very much" interested today) and maybe Terry Venables. The final decision will be made some time by Fulham chairman and Egyptian citizen Mohamed Al-Fayed. And whatever choice he makes, we are sure it will be the rational one. Hang on a second, is that the phone?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LEG - ENSRAUM

webTitle: The Most Beautiful Boy in the World

fields.headline: The Most Beautiful Boy in the World
fields.standfirst: Post your questions for Tony Parsons
fields.trailText: The Most Beautiful Boy in the World
fields.body:
It's a boy, it's a boy!

It's a little boy.

I look at this baby - as bald, wrinkled and scrunched up as an old man - and something chemical happens inside me.

It - I mean he - looks like the most beautiful baby in the history of the world. Is it - he - really the most beautiful baby in the history of the world? Or is that just my biological programming kicking in? Does everyone feel this way? Even people with plain babies? Is our baby really so beautiful?

I honestly can't tell.

The baby is sleeping in the arms of the woman I love. I sit on the edge of the bed and stare at the pair of them, feeling like I belong in this room with this woman and this baby in a way that I have never belonged anywhere.

After all the excitement of the last twenty-four hours, I am suddenly overwhelmed, feeling something - gratitude, happiness, love - well up inside me and threaten to spill out.

I am afraid that I am going to disgrace myself - spoil everything, smudge the moment - with tears. But then the baby wakes up and starts squawking for food and we - me and the woman I love - laugh out loud, laugh with shock and wonder.

It's a small miracle. And although we can't escape the reality of everyday life - when do I have to get back to work? - the day is glazed with real magic. We don't really talk about the magic. But we can feel it all around.

Later my parents are there. When she is done with the hugs and kisses, my mother counts the baby's fingers and toes, checking for webbed feet. But he is fine, the baby is fine.

"He's a little smasher," my mum says. "A little smasher!"

My father looks at the baby and something inside him seems to melt.

There are many good things about my father, but he is not a soft man, he is not a sentimental man. He doesn't gurgle and coo over babies in the street. My father is a good man, but the things he has gone through in his life mean that he is also a hard man. Today some ice deep inside him begins to crack and I can tell he feels it too.

This is the most beautiful baby in the world.

I give my father a bottle I bought months ago. It is bourbon. My father only drinks beer and whisky, but he takes the bottle with a big grin on his face. The label on the bottle says "Old Granddad". That's him. That's my father.

And I know today that I have become more like him. Today I am a father too. All the supposed landmarks of manhood - losing my virginity, getting my driving licence, voting for the first time - were all just the outer suburbs of my youth. I went through all those things and came out the other side fundamentally unchanged, still a boy.

But now I have helped to bring another human being into the world.

Today I became what my father has been for ever.

Today I became a man.

I am twenty-five years old.

Chapter One

Some situations to avoid when preparing for your all-important, finally-I-am-fully-grown thirtieth birthday.

Having a one-night stand with a colleague from work.

The rash purchase of luxury items you can't afford. Being left by your wife.

Losing your job.

Suddenly becoming a single parent.

If you are coming up to thirty, whatever you do, don't do any of that.

It will fuck up your whole day.

Thirty should be when you think - these are my golden years, these are my salad days, the best is yet to come - and all that old crap.

You are still young enough to stay up all night, but you are old enough to have a credit card. All the uncertainties and poverty of your teens and twenties are finally over - and good riddance to the lot of them - but the sap is still rising.

Thirty should be a good birthday. One of the best.

But how to celebrate reaching the big three-oh? With a collection of laughing single friends in some intimate bar or restaurant? Or surrounded by a loving wife and adoring small children in the bosom of the family home?

There has to be a good way of turning thirty. Perhaps they are all good ways.

All my images of this particular birthday seemed to be derived from some glossy American sitcom. When I thought of turning thirty, I thought of attractive thirty-nothing marrieds snogging like teens in heat while in the background a gurgling baby crawls across some polished parquet floor, or I saw a circle of good-looking, wise-cracking friends drinking latte and showing off their impressive knitwear while wryly bemoaning the dating game. That was my problem. When I thought of turning thirty, I thought of somebody else's life.

That's what thirty should be - grown-up without being disappointed, settled without being complacent, worldly wise, but not so worldly wise that you feel like chucking yourself under a train. The time of your life.

By thirty you have finally realised that you are not going to live for ever, of course. But surely that should only make the laughing, latte-drinking present taste even sweeter? You shouldn't let your inevitable death put a damper on things. Don't let the long, slow slide to the grave get in the way of a good time.

Whether you are enjoying the last few years of unmarried freedom, or have recently moved on to a more adult, more committed way of life with someone you love, it's difficult to imagine a truly awful way of turning thirty.

But I managed to find one somehow.

The car smelled like somebody else's life. Like freedom.

It was parked right in the window of the showroom, a wedge-shaped sports car which, even with its top off, looked as sleek and compact as a muscle.

Naturally it was red - a flaming, testosterone-stuffed red.

When I was a little bit younger, such blatant macho corn would have made me sneer, or snigger, or puke, or all of the above.

Now I found it didn't bother me at all. In fact, it seemed to be just what I was looking for at this stage of my life.

I'm not really the kind of man who knows what cars are called, but I had made it my business - furtively lingering over the ads in glossy magazines - to find out the handle of this particular hot little number. Yes, it's true. Our eyes had met before.

But its name didn't really matter. I just loved the way it looked. And that smell. Above all, that smell. That anything-can-happen smell. What was it about that smell?

Amidst the perfume of leather, rubber and all those yards of freshly sprayed steel, you could smell a heartbreaking newness, a newness so shocking that it almost overwhelmed me. This newness intimated another world that was limitless and free, an open road leading to all the unruined days of the future. Somewhere they had never heard of traffic cones or physical decay or my thirtieth birthday.

I knew that smell from somewhere and I recognised the way it made me feel. Funnily enough, it reminded me of that feeling you get when you hold a newborn baby.

The analogy was far from perfect - the car couldn't squint up at me with eyes that had just started to see, or grasp one of my fingers in a tiny, tiny fist, or give me a gummy little smile. But for a moment there it felt like it just might.

"You only live once," the car salesman said, his heels clicking across the showroom floor.

I smiled politely, indicating that I would have to think that one over.

"Are you in the market for some serious fun?" he said. "Because if the MGF is about one thing, it's about fun."

While he gave me his standard sales pitch, he was sizing me up, trying to decide if I was worth a test drive.

He was pushy, but not so pushy that it made your flesh crawl. He was just doing his job. And despite my weekend clothes - which because of the nature of my work were not really so different from my weekday clothes - he must have seen a man of substance. A fast-track career looking for some matching wheels. Young, free and single. A life as carefree as a lager commercial. How wrong can you be?

"This model has the Variable Valve Control system," he said, with what seemed like genuine enthusiasm. "The opening period of the inlet valves can be varied by altering the rotational speed of each cam lobe."

What the fuck was he going on about? Was it something to do with the engine?

"A total babe magnet," he said, noting my dumbfounded expression. "Plenty of poke. A young single guy couldn't do any better than the MGE."

This was my kind of sales pitch. Forget the technical guff, just tell me that you can lose yourself in a car like this. Let me know you can lose yourself. That's what I wanted to hear.

The salesman was distracted by something on the street, and I followed his gaze out of the showroom's plate-glass wall.

He was looking at a tall blonde woman holding the hand of a small boy wearing a Star Wars T-shirt. They were surrounded by bags of supermarket shopping. And they were watching us.

Even framed by all those plastic carrier bags and chaperoning a little kid, the woman was the kind that you look at more than once.

What you noticed about her child - and he was certainly her child - was that he was carrying a long, plastic tube with a dull light glowing faintly inside.

If you had been to the cinema at any time over the last twenty years you would recognise it as a light sabre, traditional weapon of the Jedi Knights. This one. needed new batteries.

The beautiful woman was smiling at me and the salesman. The little kid pointed his light sabre, as if about to strike us down.

"Daddy," he mouthed from the other side of the plate-glass wall which divided us. You couldn't hear him, but that's what he was saying.

"My wife and son," I said, turning away, but not before I caught the disappointment in the salesman's eyes. "Got to go."

Daddy. That's me. Daddy.

"You don't even like cars," my wife reminded me, edging our old VW estate through the thick early evening traffic.

"Just looking."

"And you're too young for a mid-life crisis," she said. "Thirty is much too young, Harry. The way it works, you wait for fifteen years and then run off with a secretary who's young enough to be your second wife. And I cut off the sleeves of all your suits. Not to mention your bollocks."

"I'm not thirty, Gina," I chuckled, although it wasn't really all that funny. She was always exaggerating. "I'm twenty-nine."

"For one more month!" she laughed.

"It's your birthday soon," our boy said, laughing along with his mother, although he didn't have a clue why, and tapping me on the back of the head with his sodding light sabre.

"Please don't do that, Pat," I said.

He was back there with the week's shopping, strapped into his little car seat and muttering under his breath, pretending to be in the cockpit of the Millennium Falcon with Harrison Ford.

"I've lost my starboard engine," he jabbered away to himself. "Fire when ready."

I turned to look at him. He was four years old with dirty blond hair that hung down over eyes that were the same shade of blue as his mother's. Tiffany blue. Catching my eye, he grinned at me with pure childish delight.

"Happy birthday, dear Daddy," he sang. "Happy birthday, birth-day."

To Pat, my birthday was a chance to finally give me the home-made card he had hidden under his bed (Luke Skywalker decapitating a space monster with his trusty light sabre). To me it meant that the best might already be over. It really did.

When would I feel the way I felt the night my wife said that she would marry me? When would I feel the way I felt the morning my son was born? When would life be that - I don't know - real again? When?

"When did you become interested in cars?" Gina asked.

She wouldn't let this car thing rest. "I bet you don't even know what kind of petrol this one uses, do you?"

"Oh, come on, Gina."

"What is it, then?"

Fucking hell.

"The green kind," I said, taking a wild guess. "You know - non-leaded. The one that saves a rain forest every time you fill her up."

"It's diesel, you doughnut," she laughed. "I never knew a man less interested in cars than you. What happened?"

What could I tell her? You don't tell a wife that some inanimate object somehow represents all those things you know you are never going to have. The places you are never going to see, the women you are never going to love, the things you are never going to do. You can't tell a wife all that stuff. Not even a wife you love very much. Especially not a wife like that.

"It only carries one passenger," she said.

"What does?" I said, playing dumb.

"You know very well what I'm talking about," she said. "It only carries one passenger - one thin, female passenger."

"You're still pretty thin and female," I said. "Or you were the last time I looked."

"What's brought all this on, Harry? Come on. Tell me."

"Maybe I'm compensating for becoming an old git," I said. "I'm joining the old gits' club, so, pathetically, I want to recapture my glorious youth. Even though I know it's ultimately futile and even though my youth wasn't particularly glorious. Isn't that what men do?"

You're turning thirty," she said. "We're going to open a couple of bottles and have a nice cake with candles."

"And balloons," Pat said.

"And balloons," Gina said. She shook her lovely head. "We're not having you put down, Harry."

Gina was a couple of months older than me. She had breezed through her thirtieth birthday surrounded by friends and family, dancing with her son to Wham's greatest hits, a glass of champagne in her hand. She looked great that night, she really did. But clearly my own birthday was going to be a bit more traumatic.

"You don't regret anything, do you?' she said.

"Like what?"

"You know," she said, suddenly deadly serious. "Like us."

We had married young. Gina was three months pregnant with Pat on our wedding day and it was, by some distance, the happiest day of my life. But nothing was ever really the same again after that day. Because after that there was no disguising the fact that we were grown-ups.

The radio station where I was working gave me the week off and we spent our honeymoon back at our little flat watching daytime television in bed, eating M & S sandwiches and talking about the beautiful baby we were going to have.

We talked about eventually taking a proper, grown-up honeymoon - Gina wanted us to snorkel among the tropical fish of Okinawa. But by the time there was a bit of money and a bit of time, we had Pat and the course of our lives seemed set.

Gina and I found ourselves separated from the rest of the world by our wedding rings. The other married couples we knew were at least ten years older than us, and friends our own age were still in that brief period between living with their mothers and living with their mortgages. Our little family was on its own.

While our friends were dancing the night away in clubs, we were up all hours with our baby's teething problems. While they were worrying about meeting the right person, we were worrying about meeting the payments on our first real home. Yet I didn't regret any of it. Yes, we had given up our freedom. But we had given it up for something better.

I loved my wife and I loved our son. Together, the two of them made my world make sense. My life without them was unimaginable. I knew I was a lucky man. But I couldn't help it, I just couldn't help it - lately I found myself wondering when I had stopped being young.

"I just really hate the way that life starts to contract as you get older," I said. "The way your options narrow. I mean, when did owning a car like that become ridiculous for me? When exactly? Why is it such a joke? I would love to know. That's all."

"The Force is strong in this one," Pat said.

"A red sports car," Gina said to herself. "And you don't even like driving."

"Listen, I was just looking, okay?" I said.

"Happy birthday to you," Pat sang, smacking me across the ear with his light sabre. "Squashed tomatoes and glue. You-look-like-a-monkey-and-you-act-like-one-too."

"That's not nice," I told him, as the traffic ground to a halt and my ear began to throb.

Gina put the handbrake on and looked at me, as if trying to remember what she had liked about me in the first place. She seemed a bit stumped.

I remembered what I had liked about her. She had the longest legs I had ever seen on a woman. But I still didn't know if that was the best basis for the love of your life.

Or the worst.
