fields.headline: Protection or persecution?
fields.standfirst:
Feelings are running high in the e-world over the RIP - regulation of investigatory powers - bill. Here, Peter Sommer gives the background to a debate between two of the leading protagonists



Have your say on internet privacy
fields.trailText: Feelings are running high in the e-world over the RIP - regulation of investigatory powers - bill. Here, Peter Sommer gives the background to a debate between two of the leading protagonists
fields.body:
To law enforcement officers it's a simple matter of retaining existing powers of surveillance under warrant as correspondence goes digital and encrypted. As many cyber-libertarians see it, the plods and spooks want easy, under-supervised access to any private activity anywhere anytime. Businesses - and not just internet service providers (ISPs) and e-commerce outfits - are becoming seriously alarmed about the cost of additional equipment and the administrative impact on their staff.

Britain is in danger of having one of the least enabling regimes in the world as Home Office attempts at "balanced" legislation too often favour the needs of plod/spook over those of citizens and business. Ireland, France, Germany, even Singapore and other countries to which many UK e-businesses could easily migrate, appear to be taking a much more liberal line.

The regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) legislation is yet another Home Office bill in trouble. Few quarrel with its aims: to bring into a single law the disparate regimes for the interception of telephone traffic, use of bugs and opening of letters, as well as defining circumstances to compel decoding of encrypted data.

But assessment of "balance" needs detailed knowledge - not widely available among politicians - of datacomms, e-commerce and crypto protocols, and the practicalities of surveillance. And the result must comply with human rights and data protection laws. The outcome has to be turned into precise wordings that can be applied by warrant-issuers and the courts.

Finally, since so much of the enforcement depends on the co-operation of private sector communications service providers (CSPs) - including telephone companies and ISPs - the laws and associated codes of practice have to become part of a manageable, affordable regime. That's the trick the RIP bill must pull off.

The 1985 telephone tapping provisions (in the Interception of Communications Act) assume voice traffic only and BT as the main significant operator; RIP recognises new realities. There are now more than 150 telco operators, land and cellular, and even more acting as ISPs. It properly includes data, and covers private as well as public systems. CSPs have to make "reasonable" provision to facilitate warrants and to do so without alerting suspects; but as suspects may have several phone numbers and multiple email accounts, will telcos and ISPs have to prepare for one interception per 16,000 lines (the current figure for telephones) or one in 500 (as touted by the Internet Service Providers Association)?

It's unclear how far the government will fund this. Even here, Home Office rhetoric that it doesn't want new powers but simply to maintain existing capability runs into difficulty: a single telephone conversation is easy to identify and isolate; not so data traffic where many simultaneous emails, world wide web requests and file transfers all occupy the same pipe and look pretty similar as data packets. How do we stop the intercept from exceeding the intended scope of a warrant?

It's in relation to encrypted data that many of the problems lie. The first situation is stored data that is seized under warrant in a raid and which once decrypted might become evidence. RIP makes it an offence not to provide plain text or a key - but who does the asking and how does a court assess if a key has been genuinely rather than conveniently lost? And on whom does the burden of proof lie?

It is much more difficult where there is a warrant for covert interception of data in transmission which turns out to be encrypted. Here the recipient of a decryption demand will be an innocent third party. He or she may have severe contractual and data protection obligations to other users of the same crypto system but faces criminal sanctions both for non-compliance with a RIP demand and for any action which might lead to a suspect being tipped off. And if legitimate users of the crypto system suffer because of law enforcement clumsiness, what remedies do they have?

One needs to look at the whole mechanism of RIP to see the extent of the difficulties: different types of activity give rise to a variety of warrants and demands, some issued by judicial figures, most by ministers, some simply by policemen. The range of bodies that can ask for (but not always issue) warrants extends as far as the inland revenue and the benefits agency.

Criteria are sometimes "for the purpose of preventing or detecting serious crime" and "safeguarding the economic well-being of the United Kingdom" (in clause 5) but elsewhere "for the purposes of preventing or detecting crime" and "in the interests of economic well-being of the UK" (clause 21 - on traffic data).

MPs in the standing committee reviewing the bill have complained about the proliferation of oversight tribunals and commissioners with varying powers and to whom the private citizen has variable rights of access as well as to information about suspected intercepts that might make such application meaningful. Ministers have justified the complexity by saying that the right balance has to be struck for many different circumstances.

MPs have also been concerned that some RIP provisions offer a covert means for the security service, secret intelligence service and GCHQ to extend their territo ries into traditional police and customs territory.

It is possible to guess why the RIP bill has taken this form: the scenario builders at NCIS, Cheltenham and the Thames-side fortresses read the same internet scare stories as the rest of us. They make projections about the powers they might need, partly to increase their influence but also because they fear they may not get another slot in a very crowded legislative calendar. And ministers lack knowledge to challenge their threat assessments.

Peter Sommer is a research fellow at the LSE, special advisor to the commons trade and industry select committee and has been an expert witness in "computer crime" trials for 15 years.

"It will wreck our e-commerce hopes for the UK." Caspar Bowden, director of the Foundation for Information Policy Research, opens the debate on the RIP bill
The new economy means we need an updated and revised framework for the legal interception of communications. But the proposed regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill won't make Britain a better place to live, and it'll wreck our hopes to create in the UK the world's best environment for e-commerce.

RIP proposes powers to demand, even from an innocent person or business, the electronic keys that will unlock not just one or two messages, but perhaps all one's traffic to date. Though earlier attempts to legislate to secure copies of decryption keys have failed, and though other countries have turned their backs on the idea, the British government is still trying to secure a general right of access to them for a wide range of state authori ties, and for loosely defined purposes. Furthermore, at the government's whim, you cannot tell anyone, even your wife or your boss, that this has happened.

This is intrusive for individuals. Business is slowly waking up to the enormity of these proposals, which have no parallel anywhere in the world.

From this seriously flawed start, the RIP proposals degenerate. They seem to have been devised by redeployed cold warriors who want to put Britain on a paranoid infowar footing. Meanwhile the rest of the e-world plans a prosperous future based on trust in robust security without unwarranted interference.

Do you still have every key, password, PIN number, cash card you have ever owned? Do you ever lose computer files by mistake? Under RIP, if you don't have your decryption key any more, you're liable to two years in jail unless you can prove to a court, on balance of probability, that the key was lost or destroyed.

I can commend home office minister Charles Clarke for now joining the debate, and his boss Jack Straw for conceding in the house that there is room for improvement in the bill, but we first pointed out these problems to the government two years ago.

Mr Clarke recently said in a letter to this newspaper, "We believe that we've struck the balance right", and that "innocent people are not going to suffer under these proposals." Ministers come and go, but the legislation they leave defines our rights and freedoms. There is nothing in RIP that stops these powers being used arbitrarily.

Although we've proposed many amendments, the RIP bill cannot be patched up. It must be withdrawn and rewritten. Law enforcement's task is not helped by unenforceable laws: we need, instead, a law that suits an aspiring e-commerce leader.

"The bill does not outlaw any form of encryption."
Charles Clarke, home office minister, replies:
I welcome a constructive dialogue on the RIP bill. I agree that we need to update law enforcement powers for the digital age. Not surprisingly though, I do not hold with your other assertions about the government's proposals.

The bill is about ensuring, as best we can, that powers crucial to keeping this country a safe place for everyone to live and work remain effective in the face of technological advancement. Some of these powers, interception of communications for example, are particularly intrusive. That's precisely why they should, as the bill proposes, be closely regulated.

This is a difficult area. New technologies, the growth of the global knowledge economy (and our desire to be a leader in it) and the penchant of criminals to exploit whatever new ways they can to evade detection throw up new challenges. Encryption raises difficult, some might say unique, problems. But we would be putting our heads in the sand if we didn't tackle them.

The bill does not outlaw any particular encryption technology or mandate the use of any particular key management system. Individuals and businesses alike remain free to use whatever technology best suits their needs. What the bill does is provide a power, where there are reasonable grounds to believe that a person has a key to unlock particular encrypted material, to require the disclosure of that key or the data itself in an intelligible form. The power only applies to lawfully obtained material. And if you've lost or forgotten a key then there is a statutory defence for you.

Neither of us wants to see criminals being able to use the latest technologies with impunity. You want to see an individual's rights upheld. So do I. You don't want to see business encumbered by unreasonable burdens or draconian laws. Neither do I. This is all about a balance and I believe that the bill strikes the right one.

The bill will not be withdrawn. There is cross party support for the thrust of what is being proposed. But as you (almost correctly) point out, the home secretary has said that he hasn't yet introduced a bill that has not benefited from careful parliamentary scrutiny.

The RIP bill is important and it deserves such examination. And that's just what is happening. We're going through the proposals in committee now, clause by clause.

Mr Bowden replies:
The RIP bill is about what it says, not necessarily what you say it is about. There's nothing criminal about using encryption, but RIP treats everyone as suspect. Bad memory - maybe two years in jail will help?

As we use more websites, email, digital TV, and smartcards to live more of our lives through cyberspace, use of encryption is essential to stop fraud, blackmail, identity theft, and just to preserve a little privacy. But most people don't even realise they are using encryption when they make up a password. You can't bully people into recording every one as if their liberty depended on it. In the real world, 10% of ordinary computer users lose data by forgetting keys - passing a law won't change that.

You assume everyone prosecuted will be a villain, refuse to say how they can prove they are not guilty, and then assure us that the innocent will not suffer! That's not the job of a politician. We have a judiciary to sort out the innocent from the guilty, on the basis of evidence.

The trouble with your "statutory defence" is that there is no evidence when someone forgets something, so criminals with a lot to hide will always plead a bad memory.

The jury or magistrate (if mode of trial goes through, people won't have the choice) will simply have to guess whether the defendant is lying. RIP requires no evidence (46.2.b.2) of an underlying (let alone serious - 46.3.b) crime in order for decryption to be demanded. So here are four questions about RIP Part.III that we've been asking for a while:

1) How can a person who loses a password reliably prove their innocence "on the balance of probabilities"?

2) The handling centre for keys in the MI5 building may be secure, but what about keys in transit? MI5 lost a laptop the other day, and an encrypting modem disappeared from No.10 in 1998. How much is guarding seized keys really going to cost?

3) Won't RIP encourage "steganography" (or information hiding), which will exacerbate law enforcement's problems ?

4) It's true RIP doesn't insist that companies lodge spare keys with "trusted" third-parties anymore, but you are making company directors liable to imprisonment (S.69) if they cannot comply with a decryption order. Isn't this "key-escrow by intimidation"?

I am sorry that you have closed your mind to the possibility that this part of the bill is misconceived. But the opposition parties have clearly signalled that they will withdraw support if their serious concerns on these and other matters are not met.

There are a hundred amendments tabled before decryption is due to be considered. Will you allow the committee to take its time?

Mr Clarke replies:
The committee is scrutinising the bill carefully. And it will continue to do so. As you assert, it's important to see what the legislation actually says.

Innocent people are not going to be imprisoned for having a bad memory. Remember a vital point. The bill does not allow the authorities to get their hands on material which they cannot do now.

The new power only works where material is lawfully obtained. If it is encrypted, and someone who is in a position to decode it refuses to do so, only then does the question of a prosecution arise. Where prosecutions occur, the authorities have to prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that a person has, or has had, a key.

How do you demonstrate that you've lost or forgotten a key? You explain what has happened and the court will decide whether, on balance, you're telling the truth.

There are statutory defences if you hand over as much information as you can. If you've forgotten your key, you might explain how it was generated, when you last used it and what you normally do if you forget it. Your earlier analogy of losing a PIN is inappropriate. I can't think of an occasion when a bank would be unable to provide details of an account when required to do so under existing powers. This isn't escrow by intimidation.

The cost of establishing the technical facility which will handle keys obtained under the bill will be met from the money the chancellor has provided for tackling crime in the capital modernisation fund. Deploying the highest level of security for such keys is a top priority. Will criminals turn to other forms of information hiding post-RIP? We cannot tell what the future holds by way of other technologies that may or may not be taken up by criminals. Experience tells us that they will use what most readily suits their needs.

The implication that the bill treats encryption users as suspect is wide of the mark. We know the technology is good for e-business, individuals' privacy and helps prevent certain crimes. It's also important to our e-government agenda. The bill does not criminalise the use of encryption. It targets the criminals, such as paedophiles, who use it to conceal their insidious activities.

Mr Bowden:
RIP doesn't target anyone at all - it's a blunderbuss which an extreme government could abuse for its own purposes. It's a pity that once again you seek to justify an unworkable encryption policy by associating it with an abominable crime.

Child pornographers should be severely punished and deterred, but a responsible government would begin to give law enforcement the training and resources to defeat encryption when necessary through technical surveillance devices, and put in place an oversight framework with teeth to see that these powerful new capabilities can never be abused. The course on which your officials have ill-advisedly committed you will enmesh us further in a culture of secrecy, which will corrode our democracy long after you have left office and anodyne reassurances have been long forgotten. A law which replaces the presumption of innocence with a medieval trial-by-ordeal is simply wrong, not "a question of balance".

Mr Clarke:
The RIP powers are necessary. But we've never said that they represent a panacea for all law enforcement's ills. We know that simplistic answers no longer work in today's fast changing technological environment.

Last year's joint government/ industry task force on encryption and law enforcement recommended that a package of measures is needed if we are to have any hope of addressing effectively the threat posed by the criminal use of encryption.

We're putting that package in place. Providing new powers, specifically recommended by the task force, forms an integral part of our approach.

They require authorisation and are subject to independent oversight. But we're also providing law enforcement with a dedicated resource to assist over encryption and forging a new co-operative relationship with industry.

These too are vital elements of the package, on which I place great store. This isn't about "corroding" democracy. It's about helping keep society safe.

It's also important to our e-government agenda. The bill does not criminalise the use of encryption. It targets the criminals, such as paedophiles, who use it to conceal their insidious activities. It's a pity that once again you seek to justify an unworkable encryption policy by associating it with an abominable crime. Child pornographers should be severely punished and deterred, but a responsible government would begin to give law enforcement the training and resources to defeat encryption when necessary through technical surveillance devices, and put in place an oversight framework with teeth to see that these powerful new capabilities can never be abused. The course on which your officials have ill-advisedly committed you will enmesh us further in a culture of secrecy, which will corrode our democracy long after you have left office and anodyne reassurances have been long forgotten. A law which replaces the presumption of innocence with a medieval trial-by-ordeal is simply wrong, not "a question of balance". Mr Clarke: The RIP powers are necessary. But we've never said that they represent a panacea for all law enforcement's ills. We know that simplistic answers no longer work in today's fast changing technological environment. Last year's joint government/ industry task force on encryption and law enforcement recommended that a package of measures is needed if we are to have any hope of addressing effectively the threat posed by the criminal use of encryption. We're putting that package in place. Providing new powers, specifically recommended by the task force, forms an integral part of our approach. They require authorisation and are subject to independent oversight. But we're also providing law enforcement with a dedicated resource to assist over encryption and forging a new co-operative relationship with industry. These too are vital elements of the package, on which I place great store. This isn't about "corroding" democracy. It's about helping keep society safe. fields.headline: The hidden hand
fields.standfirst: David Shayler site
fields.trailText: The allegation by David Shayler that the espionage agency MI6 plotted to assassinate Colonel Gadafy of Libya has always suffered from limited corroboration. But now the dam of new evidence is bursting open. Last month a 1995 MI6 report was leaked confirming the existence of a murder plan by Libyan fundamentalists and discussing whether Britain should support it.
fields.body:
The allegation by David Shayler that the espionage agency MI6 plotted to assassinate Colonel Gadafy of Libya has always suffered from limited corroboration. But now the dam of new evidence is bursting open. Last month a 1995 MI6 report was leaked confirming the existence of a murder plan by Libyan fundamentalists and discussing whether Britain should support it.

And today, despite the legal pressure being put on British media who try to publish details, I can reveal proof that, while the coup plot was getting under way, a simultaneous MI6 operation discredited the Gadafy family.

A smear story was planted on a British newspaper, linking Gadafy's son to an attempted international currency fraud. The story given to the Sunday Telegraph represented a highwater mark for a shadowy MI6 programme called I/Ops - "Information Operations", whose activities within Fleet Street have never before been so clearly exposed.

However, the successful I/Ops operation generated a curious libel dispute: Colonel Gadafy's son, Saif al-Islam is currently suing the Sunday paper. His British lawyers, Eversheds, said last week that the allegations are false and he was not involved in any "fake currency" scams. It is beneath that legal surface that there lurks the story of the hidden hand of MI6.

I am prevented, like the rest of the British press, by a government injunction, from revealing what Shayler himself knows. He was Libyan desk officer for MI6's sister organisation, the security service, at the time. He is plainly in possession of important information, for Eversheds are this week seeking a lengthy statement from the exiled MI5 man to use as evidence.

The origins of MI6's black propaganda scheme go back to the summer of 1995. In that year the son of Gadafy's most influential adviser, Major Jalloud, slipped into London. This caused consternation inside MI6 - even though Jalloud Junior did nothing more sinister than frequent the city's nightclubs.

So when MI6 learnt about a plan by Gadafy's son to visit the UK too, in July 1995, they apparently scuppered it. Saif Gadafy, then a 22-year-old architectural graduate from Al Fateh University in Tripoli, was refused entry because it was "not conducive to the public good".

Meanwhile, a discreet lunch on October 19 1995 was attended by Malcolm Rifkind, then Conservative foreign secretary, two senior diplomats and several Sunday Telegraph journalists. Rifkind briefed the Telegraph staff, non-attributably, about the danger of "certain Arab countries" obtaining nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. He said arms proliferation was funded by clandestine schemes to obtain "hard currency", usually US dollars. Con Coughlin, then chief foreign correspondent, felt encouraged to pursue the matter.

He set up two lengthy briefings - on October 25 and October 31 - with a senior MI6 officer with whom he had dealt for several years. The intelligence officer informed him that an Austrian company was raising hard currency for Iran to fund its weapons programme by selling oil on the black market.

But MI6 had also received a dramatic approach from another country. Details were being handed over to them of an assassination attempt on Col Gadafy, planned for the following February by dissidents in Libya. The conspirators wanted British backing. Full debriefing of their contact among the conspirators, code-named Tunworth, happened in "late November", the leaked MI6 report records. At that point, Con Coughlin of the Sunday Telegraph was put in touch with a second MI6 officer who explained there was a "Gadafy connection" to the currency operations they had been discussing.

One of the Telegraph's own legal documents puts it thus: "On 21 November 1995 Mr Coughlin had a private luncheon meeting with Source A, who introduced him to another senior security official (Source B) whom he described as having expertise in Middle East banking and finance, and as possessing particular knowledge of Egypt. In the course of this meeting Source B explained the plaintiff's connection with ... the failed money-laundering plan ... Source B made these disclosures under the guarantee from Mr Coughlin of complete confidentiality."

The next day the two intelligence men briefed the journalist for four hours. They spun a complex but intriguing tale. MI6 said Gadafy's son was authorised by his father to enter into a money-laundering deal with Iranian middlemen. The Swiss branch of an international finance company was used to hide Libyan official involvement.

The elaborate scheme involved the movement of a "clean" $8bn in dollars out of banks in Egypt. In return the Libyans agreed to transfer to the Egyptians the same sum in Libyan dinars for a massive commission. But one of the middlemen intended to use the deal to pass off a huge quantity of fake Iranian currency. At first the Egyptians were tempted as they stood to make a handsome profit. The bankers only rejected the scheme when MI6 tipped them off that Gadafy's son was involved.

Coughlin asked for hard evidence: the next day, Thursday November 23 1995, the two intelligence officers showed him photocopies of what purported to be banking records proving Saif Gadafy's business links with one of the Iranian middleman. But the MI6 men refused to allow him to make copies. Three days later, the Sunday Telegraph published the story MI6 had supplied. Headlined "Gadafy's Son Linked to Sting on Iran", the article alleged that Saif Gadafy was "an untrustworthy maverick" who was linked to "an outrageous plan to flood Iran with fake currency".

The story was entirely unsourced, except for an anonymous quote from "a British banking official". That was untrue. In reality, he was a senior MI6 officer. The editor of the Sunday Telegraph, Dominic Lawson, told me last night: "We stand by the story which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph." He added: "In common, I believe, with the Guardian, we are not in the habit of discussing our journalistic sources."

The question Saif's lawyers now want to ask David Shayler, is: was that intelligence man the same MI6 officer - codenamed PT16/B - whom Shayler alleges was, at the very same time period, supporting the conspiracy to topple Gadafy, and arranging for the rest of Whitehall to be circulated with the conspiracy's details?

While the present government continues to refuse an inquiry into the Gadafy assassination allegations, and instead seeks to intimidate critical journalists, the answer to that question may prove explosive.

 Mark Hollingsworth is the author, with Nick Fielding, of Defending the Realm - MI5 and the Shayler Affair (Andre Deutsch)

fields.headline: My brief encounter
fields.standfirst: David Shayler site
fields.trailText: Could I have plotted to kill Colonel Gadafy? If the former MI5 officer and newspaper trainee, David Shayler is to be believed, that's the kind of thing MI6 agents get up to. However, I don't recall bumping off foreign heads of state being in the job description when MI6 interviewed me for a post with the "coordination staff" of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.
fields.body:
Could I have plotted to kill Colonel Gadafy? If the former MI5 officer and newspaper trainee, David Shayler is to be believed, that's the kind of thing MI6 agents get up to. However, I don't recall bumping off foreign heads of state being in the job description when MI6 interviewed me for a post with the "coordination staff" of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

Our foreign intelligence department goes under a number of different names: SIS, MI6 and this "coordination staff". However it was not a term I recognised when I saw it at the top of a note that had arrived in my pigeonhole at Somerville College, Oxford.

The letter explained that I'd been recommended for a post as a junior diplomat with additional "special duties". I guessed that meant spying. For I had never applied to join the FO and we all knew that university dons with intelligence connections were used as talent spotters by secret service chiefs.

Most of these talent spotters were misogynists. But at Somerville our principal was Daphne (now Baroness) Park - a woman who looked as innocent as Margaret Rutherford, but had been MI6's woman in Hanoi during the Vietnam war.

Furthermore I had, unwittingly, met someone who was still a senior member of MI6. I've heard this soft-voiced chameleon being compared to John Le Carré's Perfect Spy. But his days as an operative were now behind him and he worked behind a desk in London. A liberal, Guardian reader, he was keen to see more women in the service.

Unfortunately, I did not arrive for my interview at Carlton Gardens, SW1, in an entirely serious frame of mind. It all seemed quite unreal and there were many moments during that afternoon when I had to try not to laugh out loud. The handsome stucco house that confronted me looked like a gentleman's club.

The image wasn't dispelled by the dark hall, where I waited before being taken upstairs to meet Mr Pink Rabbit, or whatever you would wish to call him. He proved to be a dark, handsome man in his thirties, who welcomed me into an office empty save for a Formica table and two plastic chairs.

Mr Pink told me that MI6 did not exist - officially. That being the case there was no written job description and he was to tell me what was expected. First I would join the Foreign Office in the usual way, by passing the Civil Service exams and FO interviews. A special induction course would follow (spouses are also given courses on how to cope with being married to a spy). Then you are sent abroad, posing as a diplomat, but in fact seeking to recruit agents and gather information.

Our human targets were the weak, the greedy, those with financial problems, or a grudge against the government of their country.

I asked about the potential dangers, but was told the bad guys "keep themselves busy killing each other". I asked about our own dirty tricks and - if I recall correctly - was informed that MI6 officers may not do anything that breaks British law, since as agents of the state they were answerable to parliament. I asked whether we spied on our allies and he smiled and said: "We would not do anything to harm our friends."

What I didn't ask was what kind of talent it was that they had spotted in me. But a witness to my first encounter with my recruiter assures me that it happened when I mentioned to him that I didnot have to shave my legs and so forth because I was naturally unhairy. I fear it is the kind of thing the 20-year-old me might have said to confuse and provoke an elder.

But while some men might have given up their secrets to hear more from me about that, there are plenty of hairy spies out there and the fact I now seem to be growing it all over my face shouldn't make any difference.

Spies, like journalists, are not brilliantly paid (they get the standard Foreign Office wage plus expenses). And it seems likely that they share similar characteristics. Both the profession I joined -journalism - and the one I didn't - spying - attract idealists who are also cynical and manipulative.

I suspect that I'm less self-contained and also less of a team player, than would be good for a spy. However, unlike many journalistic colleagues, I don't regard spies as bogeymen. MI6 is as much a pillar of democracy as the Guardian, and if an assault on free speech can be an assault on democracy, so too can an assault on secrecy. We should be united in contempt for David Shayler - a man who has failed at both professions. But then, behind closed doors, many of us are.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Fab Feb for cinema admissions, Meena Suvari weds, Dustin Hoffman to work with Claude Lelouch, and the naked WI are in demand
fields.body:
 Booming cinema admissions in Britain last month resulted in the best February since 1971, according to figures released by Carlton Screen Advertising. Some 17.6m people visited the cinema during February, a 23% increase on the same month last year. The healthy box-office was primarily down to the astonishing success of Disney's Toy Story 2, though other films (American Beauty, The Beach) also helped beef up the figures. Carlton claim that 139.1m people visited the cinema during 1999 and estimate that the figure will push up to 145m this year.

 Those who felt that Meena Suvari - the teen temptress in American Beauty - was looking surprisingly house-wifey at Sunday night's Oscars may well have been right. It was announced yesterday that the 21year-old actress had got married two weeks before. Suvari wed her cinematographer boyfriend Robert Brinkman, 38, in a secret ceremony in Northern California.

 Dustin Hoffman is rumoured to have committed to star in an English-language thriller written and directed by prolific French film-maker Claude Lelouch (A Man and a Woman). Hoffman and Lelouch first met at the 1997 Cannes Film Festival and Lelouch apparently wrote the lead role of his next project, T for Thriller, with the Oscar-nominated actor specifically in mind. Hoffman is reported to have agreed to take the role in a meeting at his New York office last week and the picture will shoot in a globe-trotting series of locations, including Manhattan, Paris and London. It will be Hoffman's second collaboration with a French director in as many years. He can currently be seen struggling valliantly to make his presence felt in Luc Besson's much-ridiculed Joan of Arc.

 Fame is already causing problems for the ladies of Rylstone and District Womens Institute in Yorkshire who stripped (tastefully) naked for a charity calendar raising money for leukemia. The story has attracted interest from various film production bodies who spy the potential for a girl-centred take on The Full Monty, but the WI members appear split on which company to go with. The rights to their story have already been optioned by Buena Vista International, working in collaboration with British production house Harbour Pictures, but five members of the Institute are rebelling and have turned down the offer in favour of a rival bid by representatives of comedian Victoria Wood.

fields.headline: Advance warning: Wisden Cricketers of the Century to be announced here
fields.trailText: After weeks of speculation, Wisden Cricketers' Almanack is about to announce its Five Cricketers of the Century in a special Millennium edition.
fields.body:
After weeks of speculation, Wisden Cricketers' Almanack is about to announce its Five Cricketers of the Century in a special Millennium edition.

The identity of the Five, chosen by a special panel of 100 players and commentators, has been a closely guarded secret. All will be revealed when the Millennium Almanack is published in the UK on Thursday April 6, but you can discover who they are by visiting wisden.com at 10am on Wednesday April 5.

Surely the panel can't bypass Bradman. But will Botham be there? And what about Viv Richards? Or Compton? Or Lillee? Tendulkar or Lara? Wally Hammond and Len Hutton? Whatever the selection, it will be five of the biggest names the game has known. Read all about it, then chat all about it at The Talk.

Don't miss our Five Cricketers of the Century special at wisden.com on April 5 at 10am.

Click here to order your own copy of the 2000 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack. And why not enter our competition and pick the famous five yourself? Here are a few of the experts' choices to help you.

fields.headline: The frail pilgrim's painful progress
fields.trailText: A frail, stooped old man moved people to sympathy as he journeyed in the footsteps of Jesus last week. For Pope John Paul II, who will be 80 in two months' time, the pilgrimage to the Holy Land has wrought a physical toll.
fields.body:
A frail, stooped old man moved people to sympathy as he journeyed in the footsteps of Jesus last week. For Pope John Paul II, who will be 80 in two months' time, the pilgrimage to the Holy Land has wrought a physical toll.

For Vaticanologists, the high point of this visit, so far as the Pope's health is concerned, came last Friday. Visibly cheered by a youth mass of tens of thousands on the Mount of Beatitudes near the Sea of Galilee, the Pope spoke in a strong voice and was in high spirits.

He even negotiated 30 steps, with the help of his cane, to pray at a historic chapel in Galilee. But one day later the Pope appeared to be paying for that burst of exertion. His face was noticeably more drawn, his complexion almost waxy. He read out his homily at an even slower pace than on previous days, with long pauses and sections that were unintelligible.

He appeared so frail that people taking communion were moved to sympathy. An elderly Palestinian man, who limped towards the altar with a cane, gave the Pope's hand a pat after taking the wafer.

Last Saturday thousands turned out in their finery, lining the streets around the Basilica of Annunciation, where the Archangel Gabriel is said to have appeared to Mary, and where the Pope celebrated mass, in the most spontaneous welcome yet for the pontiff during this historic visit.

Two millennia after Christ, most of the 60,000 people of Nazareth are Muslim, but the city in northern Israel remains the heart of the Christian community in Galilee.

"He is giving us hope. We know there are no easy solutions for us now, but maybe his coming will bring a miracle," said Rose Salem. Such hopes trailed the Pope as he made his pilgrim's progress, ending at the great shrine of all three faiths in old Jerusalem.

The Palestinian leader jumped up nimbly to greet him: "Welcome to Palestine, and to holy Jerusalem, the eternal capital of Palestine."

webTitle: Legal challenge to school start for 4-year-olds

fields.headline: Legal challenge to school start for 4-year-olds
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is facing a legal challenge from parents demanding the right to stop their children starting school too young, in what will be a human rights test case if it goes to court.
fields.body:
The government is facing a legal challenge from parents demanding the right to stop their children starting school too young, in what will be a human rights test case if it goes to court.

Details of the move emerged yesterday as the Pre-School Learning Alliance announced that some 3,500 voluntary pre-school groups and playgroups in England would be forced to close this year because parents are increasingly under pressure to make their children take up school places at the age of four in order to avoid losing them.

Leah Brown, a mother of two from from Hendon, north London, believes it is a violation of a child's human rights to be forced into formal education before he or she is ready. She is seeking legal aid to challenge ministers under European human rights legislation which will be ratifed under English law in October, and claims her campaign is gathering momentum as more and more parents support her.

"I believe very strongly that it is a violation of children's human rights to be forced into school before they are mature enough to benefit from it," she said yesterday. "We have only got one chance to educate our children, so why pack them off to school before they are ready?"

Generally, children start school when they have turned five, but four-year-olds born in the summer are increasingly offered places in reception or nursery classes. Ms Brown's two-and-a-half year old son - born on August 30 - would start school having just turned five, for example, which she believes is far too young.

Giving evidence yesterday to the influential education select committee, the PLA's chief executive, Margaret Lochrie, disclosed the results of an NOP survey which showed that a record number of pre-school groups - which are run predominantly by parents and volunteers - believed they were likely to have to close this year.

Since 1997, 2,000 pre-schools have closed and a further 1,500 avoided closure only because they received emergency funding from the Department for Education. Mrs Lochrie said: "Pre-schools have shown themselves ready and willing to contribute to the expansion of nursery education and childcare - the majority are now inspected by Ofsted. However, many pre-schools are struggling to make ends meet and this is why they are closing."

Questioned by MPs about the quality of pre-school groups, Mrs Lochrie said that Ofsted inspections of pre-school groups and nurseries showed that 98% were providing a standard of teaching that was "satisfactory or better".

The government responded by announcing a further £500,000 rescue package for groups with short-term difficulties, which the PLA claimed would mean only £15 per group under threat. It also announced the results of a survey of parents which showed that 89% of parents with summer-born children were happy for them to attend a reception class.

The employment and education minister, Margaret Hodge, said: "The survey findings clearly show that parents of summer-born children who chose to send their children to a reception class had enough information and did not feel pressurised into transferring their child and were happy with the decision they made. Many parents see reception classes as good preparation for school by encouraging discipline and developing early literacy and numeracy skills."

The department also questioned the findings of the NOP survey, claiming that 222 out of the 722 groups that participated in the research were parent and toddler groups, which were "not a serious alternative" to nurseries.

webTitle: Demon pays £250,000 to settle internet libel case

fields.headline: Demon pays £250,000 to settle internet libel case
fields.trailText: Demon Internet has paid £250,000 to settle a court case against a man who alleged he was libelled on discussion threads run by the company.
fields.body:
Demon Internet has paid £250,000 to settle a court case against a man who alleged he was libelled on discussion threads run by the company.

Laurence Godfrey took the UK internet service provider to court after allegedly defamatory postings about him appeared in newsgroups. It was the first case of its kind in the English courts and one that could have far-reaching implications for publishers of online material in the UK.

His action related to a message posted in 1997 on soc.culture.thai, purportedly coming from him and containing damaging allegations of a personal nature.

He said he had asked Demon to remove the message but the service provider had refused. The message was copied to its servers around the world and many other newsgroups.

In a case that Demon had previously said would affect the entire ethos of free speech on the internet, Dr Godfrey alleged that the company had failed to remove defamatory material about him from a newsgroup it hosted. The case hinged on whether Demon could be treated as the publisher of the material.

The case will affect other service providers, all of which host robust and often vicious newsgroups. But any moves among them to become more cautious about what they allow to be published will inflame the debate about freedom of speech on the net.

Under English law service providers are not held to have been the publishers of defamatory material providing they satisfy two criteria. They must prove they took reasonable care to ensure such material was not published, and, once alerted to a problem, took steps to resolve it.

fields.headline: Railtrack unveils £52bn spending plan
fields.trailText: Railtrack today outlined a much larger than expected spending plan for Britain's ageing rail system, amid growing concern over train safety after last year's disaster at Paddington in which 31 people died.
fields.body:
Railtrack today outlined a much larger than expected spending plan for Britain's ageing rail system, amid growing concern over train safety after last year's disaster at Paddington in which 31 people died.

The proposals costing nearly £52bn over the next 12 years are much higher than a £27bn 10-year spending plan outlined by Railtrack last year. The company said the increase reflected forecasts that passenger traffic on trains would rise by 4% a year.

The plan includes more than £22bn for maintaining the existing network and just over £29bn on improvements. The company must now convince investors that its prospects for profit are good enough to warrant such a large investment, despite tight government limits on its ability to raise passenger charges.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said the spending plan - the annual network management statement - was provisional and depended on several other official reviews of the industry. "The regulatory review, franchise re-negotiation and the government's 10-year plan are all critical milestones," he said. "This document puts forward our case and the options."

Steve Marshall, Railtrack's finance director, said it was up to rail companies and the government to decide the final spending figure. "You do not go into a restaurant and order the whole menu, you make choices. It will be up to the industry and government to make those choices," he said.

Railtrack has been the owner and operator of Britain's network of railways and stations since they were privatised in 1996 by the Conservative government under John Major. The rail network continues to be a daily source of irritation for millions of commuters. Two days ago, the industry watchdog, Tom Winsor, accused Railtrack of not providing enough details on its plans for upgrading the West Coast main line.

Jonathan Bray, of the pressure group Transport 2000, welcomed the increased spending plans, but warned that the government must put money into the railways, or Railtrack would be forced to make the passengers foot the bill.

George Muir, the director general of the association of train operating companies, said the improvements identified by Railtrack were not all commercially fundable. "Passenger train companies have consistently contributed £200m a year to the Treasury's coffers. We would like to see that sum, and more, ploughed back into investment in the industry to the benefit of new and existing passengers," he said.

Stewart Francis, chairman of the central rail users' consultative committee, the national watchdog representing passengers, gave the proposals a guarded welcome, calling them a crucial moment for passengers and the railways. But the committee felt the proposals did not list priorities, nor list the benefits to passengers of each potential project , and failed to dispel much of the uncertainty facing the industry over the replacement of franchises.

fields.headline: Secret harmonies
fields.trailText: Although I haven't checked with his newspaper shop down in Somerset, I think it can be said with some confidence that the novelist Anthony Powell, who died on Tuesday at the age of 94, was not a Guardian reader
fields.body:
Although I haven't checked with his newspaper shop down in Somerset, I think it can be said with some confidence that the novelist Anthony Powell, who died on Tuesday at the age of 94, was not a Guardian reader. Nor was his 12- volume sequence, A Dance to the Music of Time, to the taste of many Guardian readers. They tend to share the view of the young novelist Diran Adebayo who, interviewed on the Today programme, dismissed the books as a kind of upper-class soap opera, a tedious account of a rarefied group of people whose adventures have little or nothing to do with the everyday lives of the multitude. There are very few folk in the novels of Anthony Powell who you'd ever meet shopping in Tesco. And this, it is often asserted, is because Powell was an upper-class snob; a charge, it has to be said, which those who have read his journals could scarcely dispute.

These complaints, though, need to be disentangled. That Powell was an upper-class snob does not mean that his books confine themselves to a world of upper-class snobbery. (Adebayo, to his credit, frankly admitted during his interview to not having read them). There are plenty of justified charges against The Music of Time. For a start, it depends to a quite alarming degree on coincidence: people bump into each other on trains or in dark wartime London squares with a serendipitous frequency which simply does not occur in real life. And though Powell has a reputation as a stylist, there are times, in the later books especially, when the prose descends into jowl- quivering orotundity. "The gift of authority, the ability to handle people", he writes of a sinister new age prophet called Scorpio Murtlock in the last of these books, Hearing Secret Harmonies, "was the characteristic attributed by hearsay. At first, the outward trappings, suggesting no more than a contemporary romantic vagabondage, had put that reputation in doubt. Now one saw the truth of some at least of what had been reported of him; that the vagabond style could include ability to control companions - notably Fiona - as well as crayfish and horses..." And so on. It's close to unbearable.

Yet none of that, in the end, really matters. All his faults are redeemed by the richness of the creations whose stumbling journeys through life he charts. In a curious way, I think Powell has paid a price for inventing Kenneth Widmerpool who, from his first appearance, solemn and spectacled, chugging out of the mist of an Eton afternoon in A Question of Upbringing, to his wretched death at the hands of Murtlock, dominates these proceedings.

Yesterday Powell's friend Hilary Spurling rated Widmerpool alongside Falstaff and Captain Hook as a great monument bestowed on the nation. "Genius of author who gave us Widmerpool" one newspaper tribute was headlined. But the more you read of these books, the more other creations begin to haunt you. Hugh Moreland, the one I like most - a gentle, sweet-natured melancholy composer, with talent, but not quite enough, unlucky in love, and addicted to drink on a scale which evokes Constant Lambert. The music critic Maclintick, with his termagant wife and his book which will never be finished, who in a moment of drunken despair throws his cherished text down the lavatory and then gasses himself. The wild, capricious, serially irresistible Pamela Flitton, who leaves trails of ruined men behind her wherever she goes. The eccentric left-wing peer Alfie Erridge, with his glowering dipsomaniac butler, straight out of Charles Addams. The Marxist poet and critic, JG Quiggin... Though none of these has become as much part of the language as Widmerpool, Powell makes them so real that one pines for them when they have gone.

Most of this group belong to the 1930s, a time full of hectic parties and the apprehension of war. These are the parts of the sequence I always liked best. Thereafter the mood seems to darken. The final books of the sequence grow odd, disturbing and ugly. There have been figures whose political views and social attitudes make one squirm, but now new characters appear, like the American academic Russell Gwinnett, with his weird sexual proclivities, whose presence is hard to endure. Even Pamela Flitton fails to survive her encounter with him.

Hilary Spurling, who knows these books better than anyone else, says the central themes of the sequence are old age, madness and death, a judgment which may not help Powell's posthumous sales at Waterstone's. I'm not sure this is wholly true. For most of the sequence, they are just as much about the arbitrary oddness of life, the way friends are lost and recovered; the way some remain exactly the same while others change bit by bit till you find one day that you hardly know them; the way people of no conspicuous talent advance and prosper, while others of flaring brilliance end up defeated and broken. Though they may have been written by an upper-class snob whose view of the Guardian I tremble to contemplate, these books can make you re-examine your life, and find new patterns there, some troubling, some consoling. Secret harmonies, even.

webTitle: Zhang Yimou: Raise the Red Lantern

fields.headline: Zhang Yimou: Raise the Red Lantern
fields.trailText: No film had a more startling effect in the west than Yimou's Raise the Red Lantern, which rushed Gong Li, a star after Red Sorghum and Ju Dou, into the superstar league
fields.body:
Until the so-called Fifth Generation of film-makers came along in the mid-80s, most westerners thought of Chinese cinema in terms of strident propaganda films like The Red Detachment of Women. Yet China has been producing great films for longer than most of us imagine. Superb films like Xie Jin's Two Stage Sisters were produced several decades before, and though Chen Kaige, Zhang Yimou and others seemed to be making a fresh start after the cultural revolution, they owed a debt to many others.

No film had a more startling effect in the west than Yimou's Raise the Red Lantern, which rushed Gong Li, a star after Red Sorghum and Ju Dou, into the superstar league. Li plays a student in northern China in the 20s who agrees to become the fourth wife of an ageing clan leader. Only 19, she finds herself confined to the old man's palatial complex, where his other wives conspire with courtiers and intrigue is permanently in the air. The red lantern of the title is hung outside the rooms of whichever wife the clan leader presently favours, and it soon becomes clear that the only way the youngest one can compete is to provide good sex and feign pregnancy. Her power soon increases, since she is beautiful and not as innocent as we think, but the other wives' intrigues and her own descent into paranoia lead inevitably to tragedy.

Yimou shot the film so that its rich colours and claustrophobic atmosphere matched the story perfectly, and it can also be viewed as a parable about the patriarchal, semi-feudal society of late 20th-century China. What's more, he never shows us the old man, who remains a mysterious non-presence until the end.

The film was criticised for trying to appeal as much to westerners as to Yimou's own countrymen, and was not approved of officially. But it remains a marvellously structured, richly imagined and well-acted piece of work, with a central performance that holds the attention throughout.

It is perhaps Yimou's most lavish and stately film, quite unlike his others in style. It is also his most resonant. You have only to watch Gong Li being prepared for the marital bed to see how well the film captures the scent of sex, jealousy and impending disaster.

Yimou, who started as a cinematographer, and shot Yellow Earth for Chen Kaige (the first major success for the Fifth Generation), is capable of many styles. Red Sorghum might have been a western, while The Story of Qiu Ju had a touch of Ken Loach about it. But he remains a master of storytelling, with a distinctive ability to ally the personal to the political. If he has recently softened his approach, seemingly to curry favour with the authorities, he seldom fails to spike his tales with some criticism and a sharp eye for official hypocrisies.

webTitle: China tries to curb selling of women

fields.headline: China tries to curb selling of women
fields.trailText: Horrific tales about the kidnapping of women and children are being publicised by China to try to stamp out a crime that is spreading rapidly across Asia.
fields.body:
Horrific tales about the kidnapping of women and children are being publicised by China to try to stamp out a crime that is spreading rapidly across Asia.

The Chinese police regularly uncover organised rackets that offer country girls jobs in the cities only to force them into prostitution or to sell them to prospective husbands.

Children are also targeted: in a recent reported case in southern Guangdong province, young boys kidnapped from the other end of the country were sent out every day to pick pockets - and beaten viciously if they failed to meet quotas.

Cases of trafficking in women and children are reportedly on the rise in China. Its national anti-abduction campaign coincides with an international conference that opened yesterday in Manila to find ways of ending the "modern-day slavery" of Asian women and children.

The conference was told that trafficking in human beings is now the third-largest source of money for organised crime in Asia, after drugs and guns.

Tens of thousands of women and children are kidnapped every year in China; more than 2,000 cases of kidnapping have been recently reported in the province of Hubei alone. Women are frequently sold as wives to peasants who cannot afford the cost of a traditional wedding.

Elsewhere, children kidnapped from the far-west region of Xinjiang have been found in the southern city of Jiangmen working as pickpockets. Jiangmen police recently a ring of 15 boys working for 12 kidnappers who sent them out with a daily quota of money to steal.

National centres equipped for genetic testing have been set up to verify parentage after the discovery of more than 30 kidnapped children in central Guizhou province received national publicity earlier this year and led to more than 400 alleged "parents" coming forward.

According to one speaker at the conference in Manila - jointly organised by the Philippines and the US - nearly 250,000 women and children are "bought and sold" every year in Asia.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Boiler bother

Matters gaseous and electrical have, as usual, been simmering at the top of our postbag. M Messkoub of Leeds is one of the many to discover that those friendly insurance firms, who charge you for "peace of mind", try to scarper when that expensive peace is threatened. He had signed up for Northern Electric's Home Service policy to cover his boiler. An engineer came round to check it over and certified it safe. Three days later it packed in and another engineer from NE found the equipment was, in fact, dangerously flawed. When, after two days of hanging on Northern Electric's customer service line, Messkoub managed to speak to a human being he was told there was no record of either appointment. Instead, claimed the human, a phantom service had been carried out on an entirely different date and the boiler's faults were found immediately. Messkoub obliging faxed the two disputed reports; the result was a letter cancelling his policy without explaining why.

"It seems the service engineer indicated the boiler was OK but we told Dr Messkoub we were unable to give him the insurance cover because of the confusion about what the engineer had said," says a spokesman illuminatingly. He has now agreed to refund Messkoub the policy fee and pay for the boiler repairs.

Grabbed by British Gas

While Northern Electric couldn't wait to be shot of Messkoub, Sheila Leahy of Swindon found herself scooped into the suffocating embrace of British Gas without her consent. The first she knew of this illicit relationship was a letter welcoming her as a customer three weeks after she had been doorstepped by a salesman. He had promised a change-of-mind form would be sent before she committed herself but none was forthcoming - nor a contract - until she begged for it. Leahy cancelled the deal and received an acknowledgment from British Gas, whereupon her existing supplier dispatched a tearful letter of farewell and British Gas wrote thanking her for setting up a direct debit instruction in its favour. The company denied she had cancelled the contract and, when she eventually persuaded it to cancel the direct debits, insisted she owed money for service she had never used.

British Gas blames the confusion on "human error" which meant her cancellation request was not processed properly. All the charges have now been cancelled with due apologies to Leahy.

Transfer tussle

DM Parish of Shrewsbury reports how his elderly parents have also been endeavouring to flee British Gas in order to save money. They duly set up a direct debit with their new supplier, Manweb, but the bills from British Gas kept on coming while Manweb was blithely helping itself from their account. Eventually they found that the transfer from British Gas had never been completed and Manweb had been charging them for services it had never provided. Manweb confessed all and refunded them and the Parishes forgivingly decided to give them a second chance. A new direct debit was set up, but British Gas continued to bill them. Manweb insisted the transfer had happened when requested, then, three days later, announced it was about to start supplying the Parishes, something it had claimed to be doing for the previous five months. Two letters from DM Parish seeking enlightenment went unanswered.

"The opening of the gas and electricity markets has created an enormous challenge to all suppliers," says Manweb importantly. "We have invested heavily in technological improvements to make these changes as seamless as possible for customers, but we are well aware that we still have further improvements to make, as well as addressing other issues like staff training needs." The Parishes have duly received an apology.

Room for improvement

Lone travellers are unfairly penalised by travel agents, feels AF Smulian of Leigh-on-Sea in Essex. "All the advertisements I see base their prices on 'two sharing a room' then add that a single supplement is available. As a recent widower, I am appalled by the anti-single attitude adopted by travel organisations." "Single supplements are one of the most contentious issues in our business," says a spokesman for the Association of British Travel Agents. "The government has had some concerns over this issue and it was last year picked out in a white paper from the DTI." The reason, he explains, is that the travel firm's contract with hotel owners is based on a price per room whereas holidays are sold per person. The lone traveller must therefore pay the entire cost of the room whereas couples get to split it. This logic falters, though, when he explains that even in the case of single rooms a supplement is usually charged, despite the fact that "these rooms are often smaller and less well appointed". However, he concludes cheerfully, "At least this supplement is usually less than when a single person occupies a double room."

Brought to book

Some of our readers are growing wearily accustomed to exorcising phantom bills. A demand for £14.48 from a debt collection agency startled MJ Bird of Maryport, Cumbria, especially since it was forwarded from an address he'd left two years ago. The agency was acting under orders from The Softback Preview, a mail order book company of which Bird had been a member five years previously. The company threatened him with legal action if he didn't pay immediately, but failed to mention what he owed it for. Nor could anyone there enlighten him. The next development was a letter from TSP, again sent to the wrong address, welcoming him back as a valued new member.

When Consumer contacts TSP it realises that not only does Bird owe them nothing - it owes him £9.20 which it forgot to credit when he closed his account several years ago. "His account should not have been passed to our debt recovery agents and I regret that this has occurred," says a spokesman.

Crossed lines

An update for those of you who have been wondering about our second favourite telephone company, 1st Line. Lesley Shaw, Philip Gill, David Gosling and Denis Dunn are the latest to share their interesting experiences with the Swansea-based firm and its service provider Cellular Operation - a company part-owned by another old friend of ours, BT Cellnet. Dunn and Gosling report the now familiar tale of woe: a sales rep purporting to be from BT Cellnet but in reality from 1st Line cold calls and promises a fortnight's trial of a mobile phone. The next thing they know, a direct debit has been set up without their knowledge in favour of Cellular Operations. Gill received his trial phone after paying £9.99 advance line rental which he was promised would be refunded at the end of the trial. The phone didn't work and he returned it immediately, but is now being pursued for two bills by Cellular Ops. Numerous promises that "someone will get back to you" have failed to bear fruit. Shaw was sent two phones, not the one she's ordered (and both in the wrong name) and two sets of line rental charges were debited from her account. Attempts to get 1st Line to collect them were in vain.

1st Line is investigating.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A handful of newspaper, mixed with a pinch of website and marinated in a pint of gossip
fields.trailText: Planet Football Manchester United could move for Ruud van Nistelrooy, after Sir Alex Ferguson asked Jaap Stam and Bobby Robson about him.
fields.body:
Planet Football Manchester United could move for Ruud van Nistelrooy, after Sir Alex Ferguson asked Jaap Stam and Bobby Robson about him.

"Alex Fergsuon has asked me what I think about Ruud," said Stam. "I told him he has what it takes to play for us. Ruud is quick and physically strong, he has explosive pace and is good in the air."

Ferguson has also asked Bobby Robson about Nistelrooy. The Newcastle boss said: "He asked me about van Nistelrooy and I told him he was good enough to play for Manchester United, Barcelona, Bayern Munich or anyone."

The Mirror Joe Kinnear is poised to take over as Fulham manager following the sacking of Paul Bracewell. The former Wimbledon boss will be offered the £250,000-a-year job within the next 48 hours. Kinnear is desperate for work after being out of the game for 16 months and has even put a message on his home answerphone declaring: "I'm fit - and available for work."

The Express There is growing unrest in the Wimbledon dressing room. Norwegian manager Egil Olsen is failing to motivate the players - and a faction at the club would like respected midfielder Robbie Earle to take over as player coach.

The Daily Mail Pierre Van Hooijdonk wants to return to the Premiership and Tottenham Hotspur is the club he'd like to play for. The 30 year-old Vitesse Arnhem striker admitted: "At the moment I am happy at Arnhem and all the talk is just ifs, buts and maybes. But I would like to play in the Premiership again. One of the big challenges would be Spurs because of George Graham. I'm sure I could work with him and show a lot of people I am different to the picture often painted."

The Sun Nigel Winterburn is set to leave Arsenal this summer after discovering he could be third choice for the left-back position next season. Arsene Wenger sees 19-year-old Ashley Cole as the main challenger to Brazilian Silvinho for a first team spot.

Teamtalk Millwall's teen star, Cherno Samba, is to have talks with Leeds United today - just two days after being set to sign for Liverpool. The £1.5m-rated 15-year-old has been at Anfield for the last four days and was handed the red carpet treatment by Reds boss Gerard Houllier. But Samba is due at Elland Road on Thursday after the UEFA Cup semi finalists agreed - prior to Liverpool's interest - to take the youngster on trial.

fields.headline: Posey to play in Josie
fields.trailText: Parker Posey will play a megalomaniac record mogul in Universal's live-action version of Josie and the Pussycats
fields.body:
Parker Posey will play a megalomaniac record mogul in Universal's live-action version of Josie and the Pussycats, it was confirmed yesterday. The 31 year-old actress joins Rachel Leigh Cook (who plays Josie) and writer-directing duo Harry Elfont and Deborah Kaplan. The picture starts shooting this summer.

Based on the early Seventies kids cartoon series, Josie and the Pussycats follows a madcap girl rock band (think Spice Girls with guitars) through a variety of giddy misadventures. Posey is to co-star as the villain of the piece: a wicked tycoon who coerces the band into brainwashing American youth by lacing their records with subliminal messages. Posey will soon be seen on British screens as an imperilled actress in Scream 3, her first acting job after a year's break during which she lived in Soho with her actor boyfriend.

Josie's other principle roles have yet to be filled. Tara Reid is expected to play the Pussycats's drummer and Alan Cumming a talent scout. Neither have yet signed on the dotted line.

fields.headline: Houston: has she a problem?
fields.trailText: The ruckus over Whitney Houston's last minute Oscar exit shows few signs of abating. Did she jump or was she pushed? And does the controversy hint at wider problems in the singer's life and career?
fields.body:
The ruckus over Whitney Houston's last minute Oscar exit shows few signs of abating. Did she jump or was she pushed? And does the controversy hint at wider problems in the singer's life and career?

Houston was booked to sing in the medley at Sunday night's Academy Awards only to withdraw after the initial rehearsals. Houston claims it was because she was suffering from a tickly throat. A statement from Arista records claims that "Whitney Houston arrived in Los Angeles with a sore throat. After participating in rehearsals, both Thursday and Friday nights, she was unsure she would be better by Sunday. She therefore regretfully withdrew from the performance."

But this official explanation does not tally with the views of others within the auditorium, who allege that Houston was effectively fired by the Academy's musical directors Burt Baccharach and Don Was. The New York Post quotes a source close to the production who claims that Houston only rehearsed on Thursday night, under duress and for fifteen minutes only. Houston, says the source, was "totally out of it" and "discombobulated. She came in on cue for one number but missed her cue for the second and sang the wrong song." Afterwards, Baccharach apparently told her: "Just leave. It's not going to work out."

This latest Houston fiasco comes barely a month after she was arrested by Hawaiian customs under suspicion of possessing a sizeable quantity of marijuana. Houston, it is alleged, gave officials the slip and boarded a plane back to the US mainland before Hawaiian police could arrive at the airport. She is currently awaiting charges which, if successful, could result in a thirty day jail sentence. Inevitably, Hollywood is rife with rumours that the singer is showing signs of coming apart at the seams.

Meantime, back at Oscar camp, Houston's "withdrawal" led the event's panicking organisers to draft in country singer Faith Hill, at a cost of a $60,000 private jet flight. This, in turn, allegedly gave rise to a major hissy-fit from Garth Brooks, who had been assured that he would be the only country-western singer in the Oscar night medley and was determined not to have his thunder stolen. Brooks is rumoured to have wept with rage at the turn of events, though supporters have claimed that he was only crying over the absence of his dear friend Whitney. Phew - and it all looked so serene on the surface, didn't it?

But this official explanation does not tally with the views of others within the auditorium, who allege that Houston was effectively fired by the Academy's musical directors Burt Baccharach and Don Was. The New York Post quotes a source close to the production who claims that Houston only rehearsed on Thursday night, under duress and for fifteen minutes only. Houston, says the source, was "totally out of it" and "discombobulated. She came in on cue for one number but missed her cue for the second and sang the wrong song." Afterwards, Baccharach apparently told her: "Just leave. It's not going to work out." This latest Houston fiasco comes barely a month after she was arrested by Hawaiian customs under suspicion of possessing a sizeable quantity of marijuana. Houston, it is alleged, gave officials the slip and boarded a plane back to the US mainland before Hawaiian police could arrive at the airport. She is currently awaiting charges which, if successful, could result in a thirty day jail sentence. Inevitably, Hollywood is rife with rumours that the singer is showing signs of coming apart at the seams. Meantime, back at Oscar camp, Houston's "withdrawal" led the event's panicking organisers to draft in country singer Faith Hill, at a cost of a $60,000 private jet flight. This, in turn, allegedly gave rise to a major hissy-fit from Garth Brooks, who had been assured that he would be the only country-western singer in the Oscar night medley and was determined not to have his thunder stolen. Brooks is rumoured to have wept with rage at the turn of events, though supporters have claimed that he was only crying over the absence of his dear friend Whitney. Phew - and it all looked so serene on the surface, didn't it?

fields.headline: Winterson's discontent at inglorious squatter
fields.trailText: Names have always been important to authors. It was only a matter of time before the practice of cybersquatting - registering domain names of the famous in the hope of selling them back at a profit - reached the ivory towers and backbiting bars of the publishing world.
fields.body:
Names have always been important to authors. It was only a matter of time before the practice of cybersquatting - registering domain names of the famous in the hope of selling them back at a profit - reached the ivory towers and backbiting bars of the publishing world.

One brave (but wisely anonymous) cybersquatter had previously engaged the wrath of Bill Gates by offering him billgates.co.uk for a measly £2m, but the Cambridge academic who has bought jeanettewinterson.com may have taken on an even mightier foe in the famously pugnacious author of Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit.

Mark Hogarth took time out from the world of theoretical physics to register 139 author domain names and "make money, basically". On the disingenuous grounds that a web presence can boost sales, he is asking writers for 3% of gross book earnings in return for giving their names back. Iain Banks, Ian McEwan and Louis de Bernières have made threatening noises, but Winterson is the first to start legal proceedings against Hogarth (a self-confessed "bit of a terrier", she also professes herself keen to "chase him round the common").

Her case - that as an author she has "common law rights in her name" - is due to be decided in seven weeks. It has undeniable moral and practical weight. The image in the mind's eye of every aspiring author is their name on that glossy book jacket, while a writer's name is also in a sense their trademark: the (literally) ghost writer who picked up the baton from the deceased Virginia Andrews was eventually forced to add the prefix 'the new', but Andrews fans knew from those two words on a book cover what, if not who, they'd find inside.

Books inspire love, devotion and biographical curiosity: as the web blossoms, author fan sites and home pages are becoming increasingly good and increasingly important. Margaret Atwood offers a resource that is both professional and personal; Anne Rice fans have a constant hotline to their heroine's great thoughts on her self-adoring site; Douglas Coupland's pages are as witty and worthwhile as his books. Less famous authors can keep their constituency updated cheaply and directly.

If you go to jeanettewinterson.com now, you find the overexcited message that 'your favourite writer will soon have a fabulous fan page'; one imagines Winterson would be willing to go to court over the terrible English alone.

And she can't even get her own back; Hogarth was savvy enough to register himself too. The moral of all this? Think ahead. If you type www.books.com into your browser, you reach the site of US bookseller Barnes & Noble. How irritatingly foresighted of them.
