webTitle: Why Garry Sobers and Ravi Shastri are unique

fields.headline: Why Garry Sobers and Ravi Shastri are unique
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who has hit the most sixes in an over in a first-class match? asks J Mathurs
fields.body:
Who has hit the most sixes in an over in a first-class match? asks J Mathurs

Two people have hit the maximum six sixes in an over: Garry Sobers, while playing for Nottinghamshire against Glamorgan at Swansea in 1968 (the bowler was Malcolm Nash), and the Indian Test allrounder Ravi Shastri, who struck Tilak Raj for six sixes for Bombay v Baroda at Bombay in 1984-85. In contrived circumstances at Christchurch in 1989-90 the future New Zealand captain Lee Germon actually hit eight sixes in one over from Wellington's Bert Vance, but he was bowling deliberate no-balls (the over lasted for 22 deliveries) to encourage the batsmen to attack a target. It was a farcical situation: the scoreboard attendants couldn't keep up, while the umpires lost track of the number of legitimate balls bowled, and called 'over' after only five non-no-balls. The match eventually finished as a draw with the scores level.

If a bowler takes wickets with the last two balls of a Test series and then with the first ball he bowls in another series, is it a hat-trick? asks Vishwas Garg

By convention it's only a hat-trick if three wickets come from successive balls in the same match. So you can split a hat-trick over two innings in the same match - something which didn't happen in Test cricket until Courtney Walsh did it in the 1110th match, for West Indies v Australia at Brisbane in 1988-89. Amazingly it happened again in the very next Test, when Merv Hughes's hat-trick against West Indies actually came from three different overs - the last ball of one and the first ball of his next to end the first innings, and this first ball in the second innings.

We've been stumped by a question in our local church quiz - can you help? How far is the popping crease from the wicket? ask Paula & Mike Robinson

According to Law 9, the back edge of the popping crease (the line in front of the stumps which the batsman usually stands on or near) should be four feet from the centre of the stumps.

Who's missing from this England team, which played West Indies at Headingley in 1976? Woolmer, Steele, Balderstone, Willey, Greig, Knott, Snow, Underwood, Ward, Willis? asks Gwyn Gould

The missing man is Frank Hayes, the Lancashire basman, who was playing the last of his nine Tests. Rather unluckily for him all nine of them came against West Indies, starting in 1973 when he scored 106 not out on his debut at The Oval. Hayes is now the master in charge of cricket at Felsted School in Essex, a famous nursery that produced Derek Pringle and John Stephenson, among others.

I'm a big Lancashire and Wisden fan. Has Mike Watkinson been given a new contract at Old Trafford? asks The Mike Watkinson Fan Club

Mike Watkinson has indeed been given a new playing contract, although his status has changed somewhat: he is now Lancashire's 2nd XI captain/coach, in succession to the former Australian Test legspinner Peter Sleep, who has left Old Trafford. So you're more likely to spot 'Winker' strutting his stuff in the 2nd XI this season.

With Willie Watson's recent 80th birthday in mind I was wondering if any other countries had such distinguished double internationals. I know that New Zealand have had the likes of Brian McKechnie and Jeff Wilson at cricket/rugby, but have the Australians ever had such a sportsman? asks Sarah Bailey

Australia has had three double cricket-rugby internationals: Sammy Woods (who actually played cricket for England as well, in the 19th century), Johnny Taylor and Otto Nothling. The last two played both sports in the 1920s. More recently Brian Booth, who captained Australia in two Tests in 1965-66, also played hockey for them at the Olympics. But Australia's most famous allround sportsman is probably Reginald 'Snowy' Baker (1884-1953), who excelled at more than 20 sports, most famously swimming and boxing, in both of which he participated at the Olympic Games in London in 1908. He won a silver medal in the boxing, at middleweight - beaten by another sporting allrounder in Johnny Douglas, who went on to captain England at cricket. Baker later made a name as an actor in Hollywood.

Has anybody ever been given out 'obstructing the field' in Tests or one-dayers? asks Kannan Tirupachanur

The only man to be given out this way in Tests was Len Hutton, of England, at The Oval in 1951. He top-edged a sweep at Athol Rowan, the South African offspinner, and the ball looped upwards. Worried that the ball would bounce onto his stumps, Hutton knocked it away, but in doing so prevented Russell Endean, the wicketkeeper, from making a catch, and was given out on appeal. Oddly enough Endean was involved in Test cricket's next curious dismissal: he was out 'handled the ball' at Cape Town in 1956-57.

Two batsmen have been given out 'obstructing the field' in one-day internationals: Ramiz Raja (Pakistan v England, Karachi, 1987-88) and Mohinder Amarnath (India v Sri Lanka, Ahmedabad, 1989-90).

Exiled in America, I lost touch with cricket for some years, until I picked up on it again recently via the internet. In the meantime, something called reverse-swing seems to have been invented. What is it? asks Frazer Ward from New York

Reverse-swing - or 'Irish swing' as the Australians like to call it - tends to happen late in an innings, when the ball begins to swing in the opposite direction to that expected. This phenomenon is achieved by keeping one side of the ball very dry (and occasionally making the other side very wet) or by ignoring scuffmarks and gouges on one side of the ball and highly polishing the other. Rumour has it that bottle-tops and nails were occasionally used to hasten the deterioration. Reverse-swing only seems to work for fast bowlers using an oldish ball (usually 30-40 overs old). For a history of reverse-swing, see Scyld Berry's essay in the February edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly.

When are England next touring Australia? asks G Raben The next Test tour is scheduled for 2002-03, which will be 16 years after England last won a series there (1986-87). The fixtures aren't available yet: they're likely to be released early in 2002.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Reverse-swing: a rough guide
fields.standfirst: It's a new sensation - or is it? Scyld Berry traces the history of a lethal weapon and gets the inside story from England's leading reverser - Darren Gough
fields.trailText: In the beginning there was no swing. When the first purpose-made cricket balls were manufactured in the Garden of England around 1750, they were delivered underarm and could not have swung significantly at such a low trajectory and speed. The 1890s saw the first conventional swing on a regular basis, notably from the left hand of George Hirst of Yorkshire. By the 1920s inswing was common in English cricket. By the 1950s Ray Lindwall was combining in- and outswing at will and at pace.
fields.body:
In the beginning there was no swing. When the first purpose-made cricket balls were manufactured in the Garden of England around 1750, they were delivered underarm and could not have swung significantly at such a low trajectory and speed. The 1890s saw the first conventional swing on a regular basis, notably from the left hand of George Hirst of Yorkshire. By the 1920s inswing was common in English cricket. By the 1950s Ray Lindwall was combining in- and outswing at will and at pace.

Now we have reverse-swing to perplex batsmen and spectators alike. Just as physicists were starting to account for conventional swing with some conviction, along comes reverse-swing to be more inexplicable still. But if its causes are uncertain, its effects are not. The evolution of reverse-swing, along with the revival of wrist-spin, has stopped tailenders hanging around and brought about a higher proportion of definite conclusions in Test cricket - often in three or four days - than in the 1960s and '70s.

And if reverse-swing is not an inexact science, it doesn't have an exact history either, as it has always tended to be a cloak-and-dagger subject, inextricably associated with ball-tampering. But it has evolved in the same way that all other bowling techniques have evolved. As soon as cricket becomes too much of a batsman's game, bowlers devise a new form of attack to rectify the balance; at which point the game's administrators (almost invariably former batsmen, if they played at all) step in to curb the bowlers by banning Bodyline or too many bouncers or uncovered pitches. Then batsmen dominate again until bowlers come up with googlies or slower balls or new forms of swing and the process continues its cyclical course.

The first instances of reverse-swing that I've heard of date back to Pakistan in the 1940s, although no doubt the phenomenon occurred in other countries at earlier times without anyone identifying it by name. Mudassar Nazar, whose late father Nazar Mohammad also opened the batting for Pakistan, recounts that outswing bowlers in club cricket in Lahore in his father's time would come back for a second spell with the old ball and find it swinging into right-handers. A prime exponent of this phenomenon was Salim ("Bobby") Altaf, who played for Pakistan in the 1960s.

In the West Indies in the 1950s something similar was going on. Eric Atkinson, who died in May 1998, was the key man here, a strong medium-pacer who bowled long spells at Kensington Oval for Barbados and West Indies and wobbled the old ball around in the sea breezes. The expert on this subject is Richard "Prof" Edwards, the West Indian fast bowler of the late 1960s who continued to do it long afterwards in Bajan club cricket for Wanderers.

He still gives a fascinating lecture on reverse-swing; unfortunately, as with most lectures, when I attended Prof's in the '80s I omitted to take notes.

The first major exponents at Test level were Sarfraz Nawaz, Imran Khan and Dennis Lillee. While in England for the World Cup, Imran recalled seeing Lillee reverse-swing into Pakistan's right-handed batsmen in a Test at Melbourne: that must have been 1976-77. From Australia Pakistan went straight on to the West Indies for one of the most entertaining five-Test series ever played. Their tour manager, the former Test allrounder Colonel Shujauddin, remembers Sarfraz and Imran rooming together and the ball starting to go round corners.

The first time I saw reverse-swing, though I didn't know it at the time, was when Australia played a Test at Faisalabad in the autumn of 1982. Peter Sleep came in at No. 6 to face an old ball and Imran in his prime: it is a picture I can never recall without thinking of a goat being tethered as bait for a tiger. Imran charged in, leapt, and his first ball at Sleep was angled towards first or second slip before boomeranging two-thirds of the way through its flight. It then veered in towards the right-handed Sleep, pitched a full length and detonated his stumps out of the ground. Looking back (a bit like Sleep did), I realise why Imran didn't take the second new ball at Lord's in the summer of 1982 when Pakistan were desperate to finish off England's second innings (they did so just in time to win by ten wickets). The English media could not understand why Imran waited until the 117th over on a flat wicket before taking the second ball. "Taking the new ball is such a clich," was all that Imran would say at the time. But now we know, a little.

Darren Gough, by a long way, has been England's leading exponent of reverse-swing. He may be exaggerating when he says that out of his 132 wickets up until the Durban Test "at least 40 would be reverse-swing" - that would mean almost every bowled and lbw dismissal - but not by much. As happy a memory of England's cricket as any in the '90s will be that of Gough, armed with an old ball, making it reverse-swing into right-handers to keep or pin them on their toes.

Gough first learnt about reverse-swing in 1992 when the Pakistanis toured England and Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis brought off some amazing displays - and England collapses - in the Tests at Lord's, Headingley and The Oval, not to mention the one-day international at Lord's when the ball was confiscated and replaced after the umpires had detected tampering, although officialdom would not confirm it. "It was mainly just watching Waqar on the telly, his action and the way he held the ball, and facing Wasim when he was playing for Lancashire, and I was amazed how he came round the wicket and made it go away.

"I started bowling well for Yorkshire in 1993. When Jarvo [Paul Jarvis] were injured I came into the side in the second half of the season and started reversing then. If you want to reverse-swing it really helps if you can bowl a yorker, and I've always bowled lots of yorkers and slower balls. I've always bowled at the death for Yorkshire too [and therefore the ball has been old]. Most youngsters bowl their overs in the middle of the innings in one-day cricket, but not me."

He is not alone in preferring Readers balls for the purpose. When the Pakistanis toured England, and some old-fashioned courtesy allowed them to select the make of ball if they won the toss of a coin, they wanted Readers too. "Dukes don't 'go' so much, and they do it later," says Gough. The Australian Kookaburra has reversed well for him too "at Melbourne and Sydney [where Gough took a hat-trick] and Adelaide on the last tour." The Kookaburra is also used at all levels in South Africa on their equally hard pitches. When Gough toured the country with England A in 1993-94, he put his new technique into practice in the "Test" at Port Elizabeth where "the wicket were bald" and he took seven wickets. A wet and grassy pitch, and lush outfield, are the conditions least likely for reverse-swing. In the Port Elizabeth Test this winter the pitch was too grassy for reversing, insufficiently abrasive.

In Gough's experience Old Trafford is the best ground in England for reverse-swing, not so much because of the actual pitch but because the whole square has been bald in recent seasons: "It can 'go' as early as the sixth or seventh over." Headingley comes next: "About 30 overs old on a dry day." But Gough has done it all over the place at some time or another, from Edgbaston on his one-day international debut for England in 1994 against New Zealand to Canterbury last summer, when he took his 100th ODI wicket in the World Cup match against Kenya and started one ball outside the left-handed Mohammad Sheikh's legs and hit his off stump.

Creating the conditions for reverse-swing can sometimes be more than a natural process. Cricket's whispered secrets include the county game when an eminent overseas player, from Pakistan, called for a bottle-opener to be brought out at a drinks interval, hacked one side of the ball with it, and wrapped up a match by reversing round corners. At Lord's in 1994 Mike Atherton dug deep (into his pocket) to get the ball to reverse, which he had seen happening to great effect in the West Indies the previous winter, notably in the hands of Kenny Benjamin. Gough laughs at the memory of Atherton's attempt: "He basically hadn't got a clue what to do," and waves imaginary dirt over a ball. "You keep one side as dry as possible and shine the other, and try to get the rest of the guys to do the same. Yorkshire are so clued in to get it right for me and Chalky [Craig White].

"My theory is keep the same side shiny - start with shining it for normal swing and keep that side shiny all the time. How it happens I haven't got a clue, it's just something I'm glad I can do because it gives you the ability to bowl on flat wickets and the higher you go the flatter they are. In one-day cricket especially, if you don't do something with the ball, you'll get slapped, lashed."

Among England bowlers Dean Headley comes second to Gough as a reverse-swinger: he made it "go" beautifully in the Melbourne and Sydney Tests last winter. Among overseas bowlers, Waqar, Shoaib Akhtar and Glenn McGrath are the leading right-arm exponents. They all have an action which gets a little outswing on a new ball and a lot of reverse-swing with an old one, particularly when delivered with a slightly low arm. "Shorter people, and fast arm," are the essentials according to Gough; "The quicker you bowl the more it reverses." The former South African swing bowler Fanie de Villiers confirms this: "I didn't quite have the pace to reverse it a lot."

As Gough says, a well-grooved yorker helps too, not merely because it spends slightly more time in the air and can therefore swing further. The full-length ball will bring in the lbws, especially on a low pitch, as the batsman pushes half-forward; the yorker will go further and hit those stumps, all the more so if a new batsman has come to the crease. Gough's hat-tricks have usually featured reverse-swinging yorkers. Indeed it is because he and Headley, Waqar and Wasim, can all bowl reverse-swinging yorkers that they stand out as the leading hat-trick takers of modern times. "I concentrate all the more now on that first ball at a batter," says Gough. "People can tell him it's reversing but he doesn't know how much till he gets out there."

Most bowlers at the highest level who are capable of bowling at 85mph or more are basic outswingers. Most reverse-swingers therefore make the old ball go the other way, ie into right-handers. An exception is Allan Donald, who is more of an inswing new ball bowler and reverses it away. Another, on a lesser plane, was the New Zealand fast bowler Heath Davis when England faced him in 1997-98.

There have been two distinct forms of reverse-swing. One, popular among Australian and West Indian teams in the 1980s, was to dampen one side of the ball with sweat and thereby make it heavier. But this method has gone out of favour. As Gough explains: "I don't like the wet theory because it makes the ball soft." The prevailing method now is to allow one side to become roughened up (or make it so) and keep the other side shining, as Gough does. But what exactly makes a ball suddenly start to swing one way first and then the other?

An erudite article on the subject was written a few years ago for South African Cricket Action magazine by Clive During. His explanation was: "When a ball approaches 135kph, the boundary layers become turbulent of their own accord: in other words, no seam is required to cause the turbulence. In fact, the seam has the effect of 'ramping' a turbulent layer off the ball. The sideways pressure is reversed; the layer on one side comes before the layer on the other side and the ball swings the other way. The idea then is to generate turbulence in the boundary layer ahead of the seam, and in order to do this the bowler has to deliver the ball at a speed of which very few are capable." So there you have reverse-swing. And preferably not on your toes on the line of middle stump.

Scyld Berry is cricket correspondent of the Sunday Telegraph

This essay first appeared in the February 2000 issue of Wisden Cricket Monthly
fields.bodyText: In the beginning there was no swing. When the first purpose-made cricket balls were manufactured in the Garden of England around 1750, they were delivered underarm and could not have swung significantly at such a low trajectory and speed. The 1890s saw the first conventional swing on a regular basis, notably from the left hand of George Hirst of Yorkshire. By the 1920s inswing was common in English cricket. By the 1950s Ray Lindwall was combining in- and outswing at will and at pace. Now we have reverse-swing to perplex batsmen and spectators alike. Just as physicists were starting to account for conventional swing with some conviction, along comes reverse-swing to be more inexplicable still. But if its causes are uncertain, its effects are not. The evolution of reverse-swing, along with the revival of wrist-spin, has stopped tailenders hanging around and brought about a higher proportion of definite conclusions in Test cricket - often in three or four days - than in the 1960s and '70s. And if reverse-swing is not an inexact science, it doesn't have an exact history either, as it has always tended to be a cloak-and-dagger subject, inextricably associated with ball-tampering. But it has evolved in the same way that all other bowling techniques have evolved. As soon as cricket becomes too much of a batsman's game, bowlers devise a new form of attack to rectify the balance; at which point the game's administrators (almost invariably former batsmen, if they played at all) step in to curb the bowlers by banning Bodyline or too many bouncers or uncovered pitches. Then batsmen dominate again until bowlers come up with googlies or slower balls or new forms of swing and the process continues its cyclical course. The first instances of reverse-swing that I've heard of date back to Pakistan in the 1940s, although no doubt the phenomenon occurred in other countries at earlier times without anyone identifying it by name. Mudassar Nazar, whose late father Nazar Mohammad also opened the batting for Pakistan, recounts that outswing bowlers in club cricket in Lahore in his father's time would come back for a second spell with the old ball and find it swinging into right-handers. A prime exponent of this phenomenon was Salim ("Bobby") Altaf, who played for Pakistan in the 1960s. In the West Indies in the 1950s something similar was going on. Eric Atkinson, who died in May 1998, was the key man here, a strong medium-pacer who bowled long spells at Kensington Oval for Barbados and West Indies and wobbled the old ball around in the sea breezes. The expert on this subject is Richard "Prof" Edwards, the West Indian fast bowler of the late 1960s who continued to do it long afterwards in Bajan club cricket for Wanderers. He still gives a fascinating lecture on reverse-swing; unfortunately, as with most lectures, when I attended Prof's in the '80s I omitted to take notes. The first major exponents at Test level were Sarfraz Nawaz, Imran Khan and Dennis Lillee. While in England for the World Cup, Imran recalled seeing Lillee reverse-swing into Pakistan's right-handed batsmen in a Test at Melbourne: that must have been 1976-77. From Australia Pakistan went straight on to the West Indies for one of the most entertaining five-Test series ever played. Their tour manager, the former Test allrounder Colonel Shujauddin, remembers Sarfraz and Imran rooming together and the ball starting to go round corners. The first time I saw reverse-swing, though I didn't know it at the time, was when Australia played a Test at Faisalabad in the autumn of 1982. Peter Sleep came in at No. 6 to face an old ball and Imran in his prime: it is a picture I can never recall without thinking of a goat being tethered as bait for a tiger. Imran charged in, leapt, and his first ball at Sleep was angled towards first or second slip before boomeranging two-thirds of the way through its flight. It then veered in towards the right-handed Sleep, pitched a full length and detonated his stumps out of the ground. Looking back (a bit like Sleep did), I realise why Imran didn't take the second new ball at Lord's in the summer of 1982 when Pakistan were desperate to finish off England's second innings (they did so just in time to win by ten wickets). The English media could not understand why Imran waited until the 117th over on a flat wicket before taking the second ball. "Taking the new ball is such a clich," was all that Imran would say at the time. But now we know, a little. Darren Gough, by a long way, has been England's leading exponent of reverse-swing. He may be exaggerating when he says that out of his 132 wickets up until the Durban Test "at least 40 would be reverse-swing" - that would mean almost every bowled and lbw dismissal - but not by much. As happy a memory of England's cricket as any in the '90s will be that of Gough, armed with an old ball, making it reverse-swing into right-handers to keep or pin them on their toes. Gough first learnt about reverse-swing in 1992 when the Pakistanis toured England and Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis brought off some amazing displays - and England collapses - in the Tests at Lord's, Headingley and The Oval, not to mention the one-day international at Lord's when the ball was confiscated and replaced after the umpires had detected tampering, although officialdom would not confirm it. "It was mainly just watching Waqar on the telly, his action and the way he held the ball, and facing Wasim when he was playing for Lancashire, and I was amazed how he came round the wicket and made it go away. "I started bowling well for Yorkshire in 1993. When Jarvo [Paul Jarvis] were injured I came into the side in the second half of the season and started reversing then. If you want to reverse-swing it really helps if you can bowl a yorker, and I've always bowled lots of yorkers and slower balls. I've always bowled at the death for Yorkshire too [and therefore the ball has been old]. Most youngsters bowl their overs in the middle of the innings in one-day cricket, but not me." He is not alone in preferring Readers balls for the purpose. When the Pakistanis toured England, and some old-fashioned courtesy allowed them to select the make of ball if they won the toss of a coin, they wanted Readers too. "Dukes don't 'go' so much, and they do it later," says Gough. The Australian Kookaburra has reversed well for him too "at Melbourne and Sydney [where Gough took a hat-trick] and Adelaide on the last tour." The Kookaburra is also used at all levels in South Africa on their equally hard pitches. When Gough toured the country with England A in 1993-94, he put his new technique into practice in the "Test" at Port Elizabeth where "the wicket were bald" and he took seven wickets. A wet and grassy pitch, and lush outfield, are the conditions least likely for reverse-swing. In the Port Elizabeth Test this winter the pitch was too grassy for reversing, insufficiently abrasive. In Gough's experience Old Trafford is the best ground in England for reverse-swing, not so much because of the actual pitch but because the whole square has been bald in recent seasons: "It can 'go' as early as the sixth or seventh over." Headingley comes next: "About 30 overs old on a dry day." But Gough has done it all over the place at some time or another, from Edgbaston on his one-day international debut for England in 1994 against New Zealand to Canterbury last summer, when he took his 100th ODI wicket in the World Cup match against Kenya and started one ball outside the left-handed Mohammad Sheikh's legs and hit his off stump. Creating the conditions for reverse-swing can sometimes be more than a natural process. Cricket's whispered secrets include the county game when an eminent overseas player, from Pakistan, called for a bottle-opener to be brought out at a drinks interval, hacked one side of the ball with it, and wrapped up a match by reversing round corners. At Lord's in 1994 Mike Atherton dug deep (into his pocket) to get the ball to reverse, which he had seen happening to great effect in the West Indies the previous winter, notably in the hands of Kenny Benjamin. Gough laughs at the memory of Atherton's attempt: "He basically hadn't got a clue what to do," and waves imaginary dirt over a ball. "You keep one side as dry as possible and shine the other, and try to get the rest of the guys to do the same. Yorkshire are so clued in to get it right for me and Chalky [Craig White]. "My theory is keep the same side shiny - start with shining it for normal swing and keep that side shiny all the time. How it happens I haven't got a clue, it's just something I'm glad I can do because it gives you the ability to bowl on flat wickets and the higher you go the flatter they are. In one-day cricket especially, if you don't do something with the ball, you'll get slapped, lashed." Among England bowlers Dean Headley comes second to Gough as a reverse-swinger: he made it "go" beautifully in the Melbourne and Sydney Tests last winter. Among overseas bowlers, Waqar, Shoaib Akhtar and Glenn McGrath are the leading right-arm exponents. They all have an action which gets a little outswing on a new ball and a lot of reverse-swing with an old one, particularly when delivered with a slightly low arm. "Shorter people, and fast arm," are the essentials according to Gough; "The quicker you bowl the more it reverses." The former South African swing bowler Fanie de Villiers confirms this: "I didn't quite have the pace to reverse it a lot." As Gough says, a well-grooved yorker helps too, not merely because it spends slightly more time in the air and can therefore swing further. The full-length ball will bring in the lbws, especially on a low pitch, as the batsman pushes half-forward; the yorker will go further and hit those stumps, all the more so if a new batsman has come to the crease. Gough's hat-tricks have usually featured reverse-swinging yorkers. Indeed it is because he and Headley, Waqar and Wasim, can all bowl reverse-swinging yorkers that they stand out as the leading hat-trick takers of modern times. "I concentrate all the more now on that first ball at a batter," says Gough. "People can tell him it's reversing but he doesn't know how much till he gets out there." Most bowlers at the highest level who are capable of bowling at 85mph or more are basic outswingers. Most reverse-swingers therefore make the old ball go the other way, ie into right-handers. An exception is Allan Donald, who is more of an inswing new ball bowler and reverses it away. Another, on a lesser plane, was the New Zealand fast bowler Heath Davis when England faced him in 1997-98. There have been two distinct forms of reverse-swing. One, popular among Australian and West Indian teams in the 1980s, was to dampen one side of the ball with sweat and thereby make it heavier. But this method has gone out of favour. As Gough explains: "I don't like the wet theory because it makes the ball soft." The prevailing method now is to allow one side to become roughened up (or make it so) and keep the other side shining, as Gough does. But what exactly makes a ball suddenly start to swing one way first and then the other? An erudite article on the subject was written a few years ago for South African Cricket Action magazine by Clive During. His explanation was: "When a ball approaches 135kph, the boundary layers become turbulent of their own accord: in other words, no seam is required to cause the turbulence. In fact, the seam has the effect of 'ramping' a turbulent layer off the ball. The sideways pressure is reversed; the layer on one side comes before the layer on the other side and the ball swings the other way. The idea then is to generate turbulence in the boundary layer ahead of the seam, and in order to do this the bowler has to deliver the ball at a speed of which very few are capable." So there you have reverse-swing. And preferably not on your toes on the line of middle stump. Scyld Berry is cricket correspondent of the Sunday Telegraph This essay first appeared in the February 2000 issue of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Online estate agents
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: We review some of the best.
fields.body:
www.winkworth.co.uk

How does it work? Houses are selected online - some can be viewed in 360 degrees - and would-be buyers then email the relevant office of the agent direct. The process then continues like a normal sale.

How do they make money? The estate agent charges commission at 1.5-2% on the sale, whether sold online or through a shop window.

Advantages: More convenient than trekking around the company's 37 London offices.

Disadvantages: Individual agents' offices may be slow to update sites. Limited number of properties in any given area.

www.rightmove.co.uk

How does it work? Collaboration between several estate agents, in this case Halifax, Countrywide Assured, Royal & Sun Alliance and Connells. Buyers view properties online, after which the relevant agent is contacted direct to take over on the sale process.

How do they make money? Commission on each sale.

Advantages: More properties than by maintaining individual sites.

Disadvantages: Critics argue that it is not in agents' interests to immediately remove sold properties, as this allows them to claim a larger number of houses on their books.

www.08004homes.com

How does it work? A private site (not linked directly to an estate agency) that lists properties for sale from a variety of individual estate agencies.

How do they make money? There are banner ads on the site, so the number of site hits is important.

Advantages: Large number of properties - 08004homes.com claims 75,000 - and not limited to a few agencies.

Disadvantages: Coverage may not be comprehensive - the site lists only houses that it has become aware of.

www.easier.co.uk

How does it work? Puts buyers and sellers in direct contact with each other, cutting out the need for an agent. Details of would-be buyers are given to vendors, who then arrange to show the house themselves or contract Easier to do it for them.

How do they make money? No commission on the sale or fee, and no banner ads on the site. Easier charges for recommending mortgage companies, surveyors and independent valuers to customers.

Advantages: As you don't pay commission, Easier claims to save vendors up to £6,000 in estate agents' fees. As site hits are unimportant, you only need to register once and the site will email or fax you with relevant properties.

Disadvantages: Likely to have a much smaller number of properties (Easier is cagey about how many, claiming only "many thousands"), and geographical coverage may be patchy.

fields.headline: No-score draw
fields.standfirst: It's perfectly satisfactory and watchable, but Xan Brooks laments the cliches and formulaic nature of Oliver Stone's football drama
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks: Stone may spice Any Given Sunday with a few pot-shots at the sports industry but the political agenda is just window dressing. Elsewhere, the film is startlingly conventional, cut from the same cloth as a hundred other underdogs-make-good outings
fields.body:
"On any given Sunday you're gonna win or you're gonna lose," rasps the hard-bitten coach of the Miami Sharks football team. "The point is, can you win or lose like a man?" Credit where it's due: the Miami Sharks lose like men. Four times on the trot they go down in a blaze of glory, a train-wreck of bodies, a shriek of bungled advice from the sidelines. But their star player (Dennis Quaid) is a few seasons past his prime, and their long-time coach (Al Pacino) is pushing 60 and team morale has hit rock-bottom. The National Football League play-offs are a few weeks away and the Miami Sharks just can't stop stinking.

This is the kick-off point for Oliver Stone's hard-and-fast tour of the world of American Football, and it doesn't take too much to see where we're headed. That the Miami Sharks will belatedly get their act together is a given, that they will battle their way, against the odds, into the play-offs is all but assured. All that remains is to sit back and tick off the cliches.

Accordingly, Any Given Sunday opens with a rigorous dissection of a football match gone wrong and then jumps behind the scenes to chart the ongoing spats between Pacino's old-school coach (all hoarse integrity and impassioned rhetoric) and Cameron Diaz's new-breed capitalist (a ruthless daddy's girl who's inherited the team). Paralleling the Sharks' fortunes is the rise of young-buck quarterback Willie Beamen (Jamie Foxx). One assumes that Beamen is meant to embody the corrupting effect of sporting celebrity: he starts off a nice, nervous rookie, morphs into an Ali figure (all strutting charisma and political rhetoric) and then strays into simple, money-grabbing boorishness. Only Pacino, it seems, has the power to drag him back to the straight and narrow.

In the meantime, Stone directs in his usual bull-in-a-china-shop fashion. Any Given Sunday moves at a rampaging lumber, and is edited in an amphetamine rush. When Pacino and Diaz are arguing in the office, Stone cross-references their verbal fireworks with the amplified collision of brawny bodies in the stadium below. When he ushers us into the locker room, his macho stylings verge on the homoerotic (lots of oiled biceps, granite butts and dangling cock and balls). The director even crops up in a cameo. (He's that bleary-eyed broadcaster guzzling neat scotch from the bottle from his perch in the commentary booth.)

But as cameos go, this one is more telling than most. You sense that with Any Given Sunday, Stone (like his character) has taken on the role of a cynical professional. He knows the scene, can do the job, but can't whip up much genuine passion for it. As a result, the movie finds the barking dog of American film-making tethered on a choke chain. Stone may spice Any Given Sunday with a few pot-shots at the sports industry (its cut-throat ethos, its institutionalised racism), but the political agenda is just window dressing. Elsewhere, the film is startlingly conventional, cut from the same cloth as a hundred other underdogs-make-good outings. Perhaps he has lost the fire that once drove him, perhaps he's merely been stung by a few flop movies (Nixon, U-Turn) and needs to prove he can be a safe hand on the tiller.

If so, the trick appears to have worked. Any Given Sunday has performed well at the American box-office and provides a professional trip through familiar territory. But there are no rough-edges, nothing to chew over afterwards, none of the garbled, paranoiac, overheated ramblings that once typified Stone's work. Even at his most risible, Stone always managed to go down fighting, to lose like a man. Here he wins - but at what a cost?

fields.headline: The best monkey scene
fields.standfirst: Being John Malkovich
fields.trailText: Being John Malkovich.
fields.body:
Craig and Lotte Schwarz's kitchen. Lotte (Cameron Diaz) is preparing dinner for various dogs, cats, lizards, and a single chimpanzee. A parrot screeches continuously.

"Shut up!" it squawks. "Shut up!"

The Schwarz's next-door neighbour begins banging on the wall.

"Shut up!" he shouts. "Shut up!"

Craig comes in, late from work.

"Sorry honey."

"Sorry honey", repeats the parrot. "Sorry honey."

The neighbour screams "Shut up!" once again.

Lotte screams - "Sorry!"- at the top of her lungs. The chimp, Elijah, is in the kitchen, stirring the food. Lotte turns to Craig.

"You know I have an appointment tomorrow morning with Elijah's shrink?"

"Yeah?"

Lotte picks up Elijah and hugs him.

"I think we're finally getting to the bottom of this acid stomach, aren't we?"

"You're just getting to the bottom of it?"

"He thinks its due to some sort of childhood trauma - he has feelings of inadequacy as a chimp, you know?"

Craig looks blank.

"Don't you find that interesting? I find that really interesting."

They stand in silence, surrounded by animals. Apropos of nothing, Lotte turns to Craig once more.

"So honey, have you thought any more about having a baby?"

See also: Jungle Book, Planet Of The Apes, Babe: Pig In The City

Don't see also: Dunston Checks In

Pointless trivia: Cameron Diaz is being paid $12 million to appear in the forthcoming movie adaptation of Charlie's Angels

More pointless trivia: Being John Malkovich director Spike Jonze occasionally works as a journalist, after beginning his print career as an editor and writer on BMX Action.

webTitle: Riding the Bullet, by Stephen King

fields.headline: Riding the Bullet, by Stephen King
fields.standfirst: Available only on the internet, $2.50, at www.ridingthebullet.com, digested in the style of the original
fields.trailText: The phone rang in the house I shared at the University of Maine. It was Mrs McCurdy, an old family friend.
fields.body:
The phone rang in the house I shared at the University of Maine. It was Mrs McCurdy, an old family friend.

"It's your Ma. She's had a stroke. She's too heavy and the ciggies do her no good but her doctors say she'll be OK."

Since my Pa had died, it had been me and my mum, Alan and Jean Parker, against the world.

"I'll come right away."

"There's no need. Come Saturday."

"I'll be there tonight."

"You're a good son."

Except the car transmission was broke, so I'd have to ride the thumb the 120 miles to Leviston. I got lucky early on, as an old man in a Dodge gave me a lift. He pulled at his crotch and the car stank of pee.

"My sister-in-law has got Anderson's disease otherwise I'd take you straight to the hospital myself," he croaked.

"You mean Alzheimer's," I said, still revolted by the way he pulled at his crotch and the odour of pee.

As we pulled into Gates Falls, his voice became animated. "I will take you to the hospital." There was something about the way he pulled at his crotch and the smell of pee that disgusted me.

"I'll get out here," I said, reaching for the handle. He held me back, I resisted. Tears leaked from his eyes as I wandered off. What had I been frightened of?

I walked up past the cemetery. In the long grass I saw a headstone, George Staub 1977- 1988. I slipped and cut my head and hit the road. A Mustang drew up. The driver had heavy stitching around his neck and his eyes were dead.

My blood chilled as he raced away. I didn't want him to know who I was.

"I'm Hector."

"I'm George Staub, Alan."

He lit a cigarette and smoke spiralled out of the joins in his neck. His lapel badge read:

"I Rode the Bullet at Laconia."

"I rode the Bullet 4 times," he said. "Have you?"

"Yes," I lied.

"Nah, you chickened out."

"Who are you?"

"The FedEx from the grave. Now make up your mind. Who dies tonight, you or your Ma?"

"My Ma," I said as he pushed me out of the car.

I woke in the cemetery. It hadn't been real but I knew it had. I got another lift to the hospital.

I knew my Ma was dead.

"I've come to see Mrs Parker."

"She's going ," said Nurse Corrigan.

I knew it.

"To sleep. Be quick."

"I dreamed we were at that amusement park where you didn't ride the bullet," Ma said the following afternoon.

I kept expecting my Ma to die. But she didn't. She carried on smoking and she lasted another 7 years.

We all wait in line for the bullet, I guess. It's either your turn or it isn't.

And if you really are pressed - The Digested Read, digested:
Dutiful son hitches to see his mum in hospital and natters to a corpse as both he and the author lose the plot entirely.

There was something about the way he pulled at his crotch and the smell of pee that disgusted me. "I'll get out here," I said, reaching for the handle. He held me back, I resisted. Tears leaked from his eyes as I wandered off. What had I been frightened of? I walked up past the cemetery. In the long grass I saw a headstone, George Staub 1977- 1988. I slipped and cut my head and hit the road. A Mustang drew up. The driver had heavy stitching around his neck and his eyes were dead. My blood chilled as he raced away. I didn't want him to know who I was. "I'm Hector." "I'm George Staub, Alan." He lit a cigarette and smoke spiralled out of the joins in his neck. His lapel badge read: "I Rode the Bullet at Laconia." "I rode the Bullet 4 times," he said. "Have you?" "Yes," I lied. "Nah, you chickened out." "Who are you?" "The FedEx from the grave. Now make up your mind. Who dies tonight, you or your Ma?" "My Ma," I said as he pushed me out of the car. I woke in the cemetery. It hadn't been real but I knew it had. I got another lift to the hospital. I knew my Ma was dead. "I've come to see Mrs Parker." "She's going ," said Nurse Corrigan. I knew it. "To sleep. Be quick." "I dreamed we were at that amusement park where you didn't ride the bullet," Ma said the following afternoon. I kept expecting my Ma to die. But she didn't. She carried on smoking and she lasted another 7 years. We all wait in line for the bullet, I guess. It's either your turn or it isn't.
